result.title: Objective
result.description: To reduce the energy consumption and related GHG emissions with the focus on new residential buildings.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of buildings designed and constructed in accordance with the new energy efficiency standards.

target.comment: At least 10% (around 80 buildings) of all new residential multi-storey buildings, for which the design is started during the last year of the project are integrating new EE measures into their design with the target of reducing their combined, annual energy demand for space heating and hot water below 60 kWh/m2.

actual.comment:
There are no buildings constructed under the auspices of the project yet.
- The entire design and construction documentations have been completed by the project for three pilot buildings. The documentations have been submitted to the State Construction Expertise for approval. In these buildings, according to their design, the specific annual energy consumption for space heating and hot water supply will be less than 55 kWh/m2.
- Since 2013, 12 buildings, apart from 3 project pilot buildings above, are being designed using principles grounded and promoted by the project. In these buildings, the energy consumption for space heating already reduced to ca. 30 kWh/m2.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Amount of reduced CO2 emissions compared to the projected baseline

target.comment: Lifetime reduction of 220,000 tons of CO2eq resulting from the energy saving in buildings, for which the construction has started or which have adopted into their design new energy efficiency elements that reduce the energy consumption for heating and hot water in the residential buildings below the current thermal standards in force.

actual.comment:
17.9 thousand tons of CO2eq.
- The design and construction documentations for three pilot buildings (in Hrodna, Mahiliou and Minsk) developed by the project have been submitted for the required state expertise. New energy efficiency measures have been adopted into the design of these buildings (ventilation heat recuperation, heat pumps on sewage and geothermal sources, solar heaters and solar PV-panels). The project has been already proceeded to procurement of related equipment, accessories and tools. These provisions allow the projected annual specific energy consumption for space heating and hot water supply to be in the range of 50-60 kWh/m2 that is by ca. 60-70 kWh/m2 per year lower than in the baseline case.
- If this design value is proven by actual construction, the lifetime (30 years) GHG emission reduction will be at least 17.9 thousand tons of CO2eq for the three buildings in total.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Strengthened legal and regulatory framework and mechanisms to enforce the legislation for improving the energy efficiency of the building sector with the focus on new residential buildings

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Status of the national laws and other regulatory documents controlling the energy consumption of the newly constructed buildings.

baseline.comment: Prescriptive thermal standards adopted in 2010 defining minimum mandatory U-values for the building envelope, corresponding to the average annual heat demand of 60 kWh/m2 for space heating of typical multi-apartment buildings and 120-130 kWh /m2 together with sanitary hot water preparation.

target.comment:
Revised minimum energy performance standards adopted for new construction and reaching a status of a law by the end of the project with a target of reducing the energy consumption of new residential buildings for space heating and hot water together below 60 kWh/m2.
An energy performance certification and labelling scheme for both new and existing buildings adopted and under implementation by the end of the project

actual.comment:
No minimum energy performance standards reaching a status of a law have been adopted yet.
- The project elaborated a draft of the Technical Code “On Energy Efficiency of Buildings”, which is based on EU Directive 2010/31/EU concerning integral energy performance of residential buildings, along with the list of related national technical regulatory acts. These documents were incorporated into the Plan of State Standardization for 2015 and into the State Development Program of Technical Regulation, Standardization and Conformity Assessment in the Field of Energy Saving for 2011-2015. Both programmes were duly adopted, and the project submitted the drafts of elaborated documents to the Technical Committee for Standardization in the Field of Energy Efficiency (TCS-14) for consideration and approval. The said TCS-14 was created by the Ministry of Architecture and Construction due to initiatives and support provided by the project. Three project consultants were co-opted to be members of TCS-14, and one of them has become a chair of TCS-14.
- As an integral part of national applications to the said Technical Code, the project drafted some new standards. Some of these standards have been already submitted and adopted (in particular “Method of calculation of specific heat consumption for heating and ventilation in residential buildings”; "Energy performance of buildings. Assessment of overall energy consumption and energy performance of buildings"; "Energy efficiency of buildings. Methods for determination of energy efficiency and energy certification buildings "; amendments to “Thermal protection of buildings. Energy performance characteristics. Rules of definition”).
- The project has prepared a draft of the methodological guidelines, based on the IPMV-protocol and in line with the best international practice and with due account of national provisions, for energy audit and energy performance monitoring and calculation applicable to residential buildings. The draft has been verified during energy auditing of 30 multi-storey residential buildings in 2013-2015 and adjusted accordingly. It will be used for carrying out of energy audits of 25 other multi-storey residential buildings in 2015-2016 and further enter a corresponding adoption procedure. Four two-day training workshops were organized and held in 2013-2014 for more than 70 professional energy auditors.
No energy performance certification and labeling scheme for residential buildings have been adopted yet.
- In technical standard "Energy efficiency of buildings. Methods for determination of energy efficiency and energy certification of buildings" the project and its partners first introduced a scheme similar to the energy performance certification system. This scheme is suggested in a building energy efficiency passport format, which is to be issued as an integral part of design and construction documentations, and contains all major requisites for energy performance certification. Next, in the second part of 2015, the project should elaborate practical procedures for the energy certification system and a system of monitoring and compliance checking applicable to residential buildings.
- To do this, the project organized and held two round-tables for relevant stakeholders, where main principles and framework of the certification system were discussed, and provided further necessary consulting services to the "StroyTechNorm" RUE and to members of the TCS-14. As of Nov 26, 2014, the suggestions mentioned above were considered and approved by the said Technical Committee for further adoption procedure. The project will continue its efforts in consulting the authorities, using in particular such instrument as TCS-14, until the said documents are duly adopted.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Enhanced capacity of the Belarusian specialists to implement and effectively enforce new energy efficiency standards and construction norms with the initial focus on new residential buildings.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Demonstrated capacity of the Belarussian building sector specialist to integrate new EE approaches and measures into the design of the buildings and to implement them in practice.

baseline.comment:
Non-integrated design of the buildings just complying with the current prescriptive thermal standards in force.
Lack of capacity of the public authorities to effectively supervise and enforce the implementation of the planned new, overall energy performance based norms and standards.

target.comment:
Integrated, energy efficient building design approach together with buildingsâ€™ overall energy performance based design principles adopted into the work of at least 30% of all local design institutes as well as into the curricula of all educational institutes in Belarus educating new architects and building construction and HVAC engineers.
By the end of the project, at least 50 experts from each key professional group (see outputs 2,2-2.6) and 200 university students have taken and successfully passed courses on energy efficient building design and construction.Key public authorities responsible for supervision and enforcement of the planned new norms and regulations trained,

actual.comment:
6%
- There are already 7 local design institutes (i.e., NIPTIS, MAPID, Hrodnagrazhdanproekt, Gomelgrazhdanproekt, Saint-Gobain Construction Product BelRus, Tenth UNR, Minskproekt), out of ca. 120 design institutes operating in the field of civil construction engineering, which are introducing in their practice design and construction of residential buildings with energy efficiency improvement components developed and advocated by the project.
- The project developed and disseminated about 40 special technical reports and guidelines on energy efficiency design principles. The recommendations with cost efficiency analysis of different technical options applicable to the development of energy efficient residential buildings were prepared and discussed with stakeholders. The recommendations are intended to be tested during the development of pilot buildings and will be included in national technical regulations and standards.
More than 70 specialists.
- The analysis of target groups along with assessment of needs in their capacity building has been conducted and the capacity building action plan for 2014-2016 has been compiled, discussed with Energy Efficiency Department and other stakeholders and approved. Training textbooks have been drafted and disseminated.
- More than 70 specialists has developed their skills and increased knowledge for leading and managing effective energy audit in residential houses during three two-day training courses organized in Sep, Oct and December 2014. One training course was conducted during actual energy audit measurements on-site.
- More than 70 specialists has taken and passed six-day training courses held in Hrodna and Minsk on energy efficient building design and construction, new energy efficiency improvement policy, norms and standards. The trainings were attended by 29 companies (designers, engineers, builders, construction inspectors, utilities representatives, etc.).
- The project provided support and organized logistics for 9 study visits and 10 international events abroad where about 30 decision-makers, designers, builders and other relevant specialists have become acquainted with design, construction and operation practices as well as with legal framework, standards and policies exercised in four leading European countries (Germany, Austria, England and France) in the field of energy efficient residential buildings.
No syllabus related to energy efficient building design principles has been adopted into the curricula of target educational institutes in Belarus yet. No student has passed the courses yet.
- The critical analysis of curricula of different relevant universities has been conducted and the proposals for its improvement and updating have been presented in a project report along with a list of suggested university courses. Based on the report, recommendations for relevant university curricular updates have been drafted, presented and approved at two round-tables (about 60 representatives of stakeholders have participated).
- Three new courses related to the best international and national practice in the field of design and construction of energy efficient residential buildings were suggested and presented by the project. During round-table discussions held in the Belarusian National Technical University conjointly with Scientific Council Meeting with presence of representatives from 14 faculties of 7 universities, three national universities agreed to include these new courses in their syllabi. The decision has been made to continue cooperation with the said faculties in order to further adjust the curricular materials prepared by the project to current syllabi.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Demonstrated energy and cost-saving potential of new energy efficiency measures in at least three new residential buildings in two Belarusian cities

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Status of the demonstration projects.

baseline.comment: N/A

target.comment:
Each of the 3 demonstration buildings constructed and reaching the target for annual external energy demand for space heating and hot water equal or less than 60 kWh/m2, and their energy consumption and other performance (living comfort etc.) monitored for at least one full year. Full completion of this outcome without project extension is moderately unlikely because of one-year delay of the project start. If the documented, disseminated and institutionalized project results should be based on the results of the three buildings being built, then completion of this Outcome without project extension is unlikely.
The baseline costs of the 3 demo buildings is covered in full by the project's cofinancing resources and the GEF financing for incremental EE measures will not exceed 15% of the total construction costs of each demo building.

actual.comment:
None of the three demonstration buildings has been constructed and monitored yet.
- Background studies, preconstruction simulations and exploratory designs of measures, technological methods, installations and equipment for energy efficiency improvement of three pilot buildings and design of all three selected pilot buildings have been completed along with application of integrated building design principles and taking into account new technologies and approaches suggested and formulated by the project.
- The design and construction documentations of all three pilot buildings (in Hrodna, Mahiliou and Minsk) have been developed and submitted to the state expertise for approval. The construction documentation of the pilot building in Hrodna has been approved. Such approval for construction documentations of other two buildings is expected in July 2015.
- The project has already procured of about 15% of all equipment, accessories and tools and started procurement procedures for the rest.
In line with the commitments assumed in writing by the project partners, they have covered the baseline cost of design and construction documentations for all three pilot buildings. Recently, the GrodnoGrazhdanProject informed the PIU that they will not be able to provide further sustainable financing of the pilot house in Grodno. The PIU and UNDP CO have, in cooperation with the Head of EE Department, approached the Grodno authorities to settle this issue. As a result, another builder is ready to take over the initiative and commit itself to provide necessary financing of the construction in Grodno. The project is currently waiting for a formal letter. The two other partners re-confirmed in writing their financial commitments to support the baseline construction, proven by corresponding Oblast authorities, and submitted timeframes for design and construction of pilot buildings in Minsk and Mogilev.
According to the design and construction documentations, the energy performance of these buildings will be in line with the outcome target, which stipulates for annual external energy demand for space heating and hot water supply to be equal or less than 60 kWh/m2, and the cost of incremental energy efficiency measures will not exceed 15% of the total construction costs.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Documented, disseminated and institutionalized project results providing a basis for further replication.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Status of the planned public outreach activities
Status of the entity to follow up and continue the activities initiated by the project
Number of visit and downloads from the project website

baseline.comment: N/A

target.comment:
Planned public outreach activities successfully completed
An entity to follow up and, as applicable, to continue the activities initiated by the project has been designated with adequate resources to perform its work.
At least 100 hits and 20 downloaded documents per month from the project website by outside visitors

actual.comment:
Public outreach activities being successfully implemented:
- 14 communication campaigns (5 international conferences, 5 round tables, 2 international seminars abroad, one press-conference, 6 training workshops, one Earth Day Event, one 3D-Picture Event, two exhibitions).
- 39 press-releases and 67 articles published in web-based media.
- 148 technical reports and 16 brochures printed or published in web-based media.
- 40 news pieces broadcasted. The partnership network includes more than 25 media resources.
- Support has been provided for 2012-2013 and 2013-2014 Energy Marathon Republican Contest. The PMU was taking part in the Contest Committee. The Contest materials have been prepared, published and disseminated in 500 CDs among schools, relevant Universities and the Ministry of Education.
No state agency with a responsibility to monitor the energy savings and CO2 emission reductions in residential buildings has been mandated and capacitated yet. This activity was initially planned for 2015-2016.
In average per month, 190 hits and 1700 documents are being downloaded by outside visitors.
- The project website test version was created as of 01.12.2013. The fully operated version was launched on 19.12.2013. The website is being regularly updated (www.effbuild.by).

location.name: Vitebsk
location.activity-description: To promote a landscape approach to management of peatlands so as to conserve biodiversity, enhance carbon stocks, and secure multiple ecosystem services with demonstration in the Poozerie landscape.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To promote a landscape approach to management of peatlands that conserves biodiversity, enhances carbon stocks, ensures sustainable land management, and sustainable forest management, with demonstrations in a number of pilot sites (peatland PAs, agricultural peatlands, and forested peatlands)

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Extent of peatland area that is brought under an effective, landscape-based, conservation and/or sustainable use regime under the framework of a National Strategy for Peatlands (NSP)

baseline.comment: Currently there is no NSP; there are a few, disparate efforts through past and ongoing donor-funded projects to restore, conserve and sustainably use peatlands

target.comment:
122,270 ha
(Of which, 30,301 ha are existing peatland national zakazniks where management effectiveness is improved; 25,036 ha are new local zakazniks; 45,000 ha is the network of environmental corridors; 15,000 ha of drainage networks on agricultural peatlands from which sedimentation is to be reduced; 4,311 ha are re-wetted agricultural lands; 495 ha are arable peatlands converted to meadows; 100 ha are arable peatlands subject to layered ploughing; and 2,027 ha are re-wetted forest peatlands)

actual.comment:
59,337 ha +
13,927 ha reserved at the local level for establishing of 7 new reserves (25,000 ha of new reserves will be officially gazzeted by end of 2016); An a network of environmental corridors covering 45,000 ha established;
An engineering project to establish a drainage network covering 15,000 ha on agricultural peatlands developed to reduce adverse impact of anthropogenic run-offs from land-reclamation systems on ecosystems of the Zvanest reserve; works will be completed by mid 2016
An engineering project for re-wetting of 3,455 ha of agricultural lands developed; 400 ha of arable peatlands converted to meadows; 10 ha of arable peatlands subject to layered ploughing; and engineering projects for re-wetting of 3,384 ha forested peatlands developed.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Landscape approach to peatlands conservation and sustainable use enshrined in national policy and implemented through a network of PAs in the Poozerie landscape

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Cross-sectoral WG for promoting a landscape approach to peatlands conservation and sustainable use

baseline.comment: None exists at present

target.comment: Working Group formed by Year 1 and receives capacity building support from partner international peatland conservation organizations

actual.comment: Another two meetings of the Working Group took place in November 2014 and February 2015, where main provisions of the Strategy and Schemes were approved

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Criteria and methodologies for assessment of peatlandsâ€™ state, function and services

baseline.comment: Criteria exist but they only take into account economic benefits

target.comment: Criteria and methodology developed by Year 2 and includes ecological criteria (in the form of recommendations/ instructions)

actual.comment: A technical code on criteria, including ecological ones for peatlands use, developed and duly approved by Ministry of Environemnt on f June 26th 2015 (17.12-08-2015 (33140)

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Inventory of all peatlands

baseline.comment: Outdated listing of peatlands exist and it is spotty (not comprehensive)

target.comment: Current and comprehensive listing of peatlands status, functions, services (based on above criteria) by Year 3

actual.comment: Inventories of peatlands in three (MInsk, Brest and Vitebsk) out of six target regions completed. Inventory of remaining peatlands shall be completed by end of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: National Strategy for Peatlands

baseline.comment: Old Scheme ended in 2010 and emphasis was on peat mining and agriculture

target.comment: New 20-year strategy that takes economic and ecological benefits into account in determining use of peatlands by Year 4

actual.comment: Strategy for sustainable use of peatlands until 2030 and Schemes of peatland distribution with instructions on the use of peatlands are developed and being reviewed. Final documents are expected by December 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Enhanced management effectiveness at existing PAs as measured by METT

baseline.comment:
Yelnya: 48%
Morochno: 20%

target.comment:
Yelnya: 60%
Morochno: 45%

actual.comment: METT assessment is planned for 2015-2016 after completion of works on restoration of hydrological regime in Yelnya and development of the management plan for Morochno.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Emission reductions through re-wetting of disturbed areas in Yelnya PA (see table on carbon benefits below for details)

baseline.comment: In the baseline scenario emissions reduction would be 0 tCO2equ

target.comment: Target emission reduction over 20 years 545,624.20 tCO2equ

actual.comment: Contract is under implementation for assessment of emission in Yelnya before completion of works on restoration of hydrological regime. In 2016 similar studies will be conducted to assess changes in GHG fluxes after re-wetting

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Enhanced management effectiveness at planned local reserves as measured by METT (local reserves have been clustered in to 3 groups based on geographical location)

baseline.comment:
Vitebsk Poozerie Cluster (Krasniy Moch, Uzgon, Bolshoy Moch, Potoki, Lebediny Moch, Zaborovski Moch, Rossonski Moch): 6%
Eastern Cluster (Esmonovski Moch, Ushlovskoe, Yasen, Velikiy Ostrov, Oster, Beloe): 6%
Central Cluster (Ushanskoe, Chertovo boloto, Surazhinskoe, Turshevka-Chertovo, Ositskoe): 6%

target.comment: Each of the 3 clusters: 42%

actual.comment: Management effectiveness will be evaluated after protected areas establishment in November-December 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: A network of local caretakers is operational in the internationally important peatland PAs

baseline.comment: At present, system of local caretakers are in 8 important peatland PAs

target.comment: Network exists for 18 internationally important peatland PAs by Year 3

actual.comment: Activities are planned for 2015-2016. In 2015 an agreement with a leading national NGO in this area (Akhova ptushak Batskaushchyny) was reached and preliminar financial and working plan was worked out. In September 2015 official agreement on implementation of this activity will be signed. It presumes using of NIM modality.

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description: Plans for restoration of hydrological regime in the Yelnya peatland PA are elaborated and implemented

baseline.comment: Plan for Yelnya at the stage of elaboration, but not finished and not implemented.

target.comment: Plans are elaborated and implemented by Year 4

actual.comment: The project is developed and passing through state ecological expertise. Hydroregime is expected to be restored by December 2015

indicator.title: Indicator 10
indicator.description: Increase in local tourism organization income from wildlife viewing

baseline.comment: Approx. $1200

target.comment: Increase in revenue from wildlife viewers estimated at $5,000 per year at all pilots

actual.comment: Assesment of financial incomes as result of undertaken activities wil be conducted in 2015-2017 for the pilot project's territories (reserves Nalibokski and Zvanets)

indicator.title: Indicator 11
indicator.description: Increase in local hunter association income from sustainable hunting

target.comment: Increase in revenue from sustainable hunting estimated at $2,500 per year per site

actual.comment: Assesment of financial incomes by local hunter association as result of undertaken activities wil be conducted in 2015-2017 for the pilot project's territories (reserves Nalibokski and Zvanets)

indicator.title: Indicator 12
indicator.description: A network of environmental corridors in the Vitebsk Oblast Poozerie landscape, ensuring the continuity of the natural landscapes and unrestricted wildlife migration

baseline.comment: Isolated elements of the network are in place, which are not considered in territorial planning

target.comment: An environmental network is developed, comprised of the key territories and environmental corridors linking bogs and wet areas together by Year 3

actual.comment: Environmental Network for Vitebsk Oblast Poozerie was established and duly approved be the Ministry of Environment and Vitebsk Regional Executive Committee

indicator.title: Indicator 13
indicator.description: Flow of polluted waters from drainage areas into nearby natural water bodies

baseline.comment: Baseline level of pollutant flow to be measured in first quarter of project

target.comment: Decrease in pollutants from baseline levels by 50% by Year 4, which creates conditions for the restoration of biodiversity

actual.comment: The project is developed and passing through state ecological expertise. Project is expected to be implemented by December 2015

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Restoration and management of degraded agricultural and forested peatlands for improved biodiversity conservation, sustainable land management and carbon sequestration within landscapes

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Water levels at re-wetted agricultural peatlands (F1 pilots)

baseline.comment: 60 cm and more below soil

target.comment: 10 to -30 cm (except for Mgle and Yurievo where target is 0 to -40 cm

actual.comment: Measurements will be conducted in 2015-2017 after completion of respective construction works at 3,455 ha

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Water levels at re-wetted forest peatlands (F3 pilots)

baseline.comment: 40-80 cm below soil

target.comment: 0-30 cm below soil

actual.comment: Measurements will be conducted in 2015-2017 after completion of respective construction works at 3,384 ha.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Perennial grass cover at arable peatlands that are converted to improved grassland (F2 pilots)

baseline.comment: More than 70% of pilot sites are arable land

target.comment: 100 ha of F2 sites are improved grassland

actual.comment: 400 ha of F2 sites have been converted to improved grassland

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Content of organic matter in soil (F4 sites)

baseline.comment: Organic matter in soil 50-70% (F4 sites)

target.comment: Content of organic matter in soil decreases by no more than 5%

actual.comment: Deep ploughing of 10 hectares completed. Organic matter monitoring is ongoing. Results of the organic content analysis will be available in 2016

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Improvement in biodiversity indicator species at pilot sites

baseline.comment: See baseline values for pilot sites in table below

target.comment: See target values for pilot sites in table below

actual.comment: Biodiversity inventory at pilot sites (8 territories of over 8,000 ha) was completed before re-wetting. Flora and fauna charactiristic were recorded, It was shown that for the pilot territories the most typical vegetation type is pine forests growing in an unstable hydrological regime with signs of digression. Populations of birds indictor species are characterized by significant lower levels in comparison with target numbers. Monitoring works will continue in 2015-2017 after re-wetting.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Reduction in GHG emissions and enhanced carbon sequestration at pilot sites

baseline.comment: See baseline values for pilot sites in table below

target.comment: See target values for pilot sites in table below

actual.comment:
Respective assessments for sites of agriculture lands completed before re-wetting (3,455 ha). Total GHG emissions before intervention: 33,030 ?(??2 eq.)/year.
Respective assessments for other sites (forested peatlands) completed in 2014-2015 before re-wetting for 3,384 ha. Total GHG emissions before intervention: 15,031 ?(??2 eq.)/year

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Revised GESTs developed covering drained and rewetted bogs for recently rewetted agricultural fens, and for the transient stages

baseline.comment: Current GESTs apply only to extracted peatland areas

target.comment: Gaps in GESTs are filled by Year 4 such that agricultural and forestry biotopes are covered

actual.comment:
Continuation of two-year monitoring of greenhouse gases fluxes agricultural on and forestry biotopes.
As of of 30 June 2015 all investigated sites were recorded for GHG exchange fot 19 month.
Emission of CO2 for one-year period was 464,46±26,66 g(??2-C)m-2 for fen in transition stage (meadow grass (Phleum) on drained peat soils for agricultural purposes, with changed land use from cultivated crops to perennial grass meadow).
emission of CO2 was 511 ±27,8 g(??2-C)m-2 for biotope dominated by Polytrichum commune on raised bogs with disturbed hydrological regime.
Emission of CO2 was 391±37 g(??2-C)m-2 for biotope dominated by Calluna vulgaris on raised bogs with disturbed hydrological regime.
Emission of N2O was negligible only on drained bogs sites. On fens in transition stage site N2O emission was 644 mg(N2O-N) m-2 for one-year period.
The CH4 emission was negligible at all sites

result.title: Objective 1
result.description: To achieve compliance with the accelerated Montreal Protocol HCFC phase-out requirements through stabilization and progressive reduction of HCFC consumption.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Participating country (except Ukraine which will request separate assistance in servicing sector) is in compliance with the MP obligations for 2015 and 2020, or accelerates the phase-out earlier than MP requirements are enforced

baseline.comment: ·  Lack of approved HCFC phase-out strategy;

target.comment: ·  HCFC phase-out strategy fully formulated and recommended for adoption and implementation;

actual.comment:
As per the data publicly reported to the Ozone secretariat, which is analysed by the Implementation Committee Meeting of the Montreal Protocol and later on confirmed by the Parties at their annual Meeting (held in November 2014 in Paris) all 4 participating countries are in compliance with their obligations under the Montreal Protocol (for the latest HCFC national consumption data, please see: http://ozone.unep.org/en/ods_data_access_centre/).
One country (Ukraine) continues to implement a specific plan of action to be followed to maintain compliance, which is also regularly discussed and reviewed by the Implementation Committee for the Montreal Protocol. Details of the Ukrainian national situation are discussed below in the national components' description, to avoid duplication.
All countries are on track to meet the 2015 target of 90% reduction of HCFC consumption compared to their baseline. Ukraine reported decreasing HCFC imports trends which may help stay in compliance with 2015 targets - this reporting will be released only in Q3 2016.
The process of HCFC phase-out national strategy revision has been either accomplished, in process or initiated in all 4 countries.
(-) Belarus: HCFC Phase-out Strategy document is approved by the Council of Ministers. It is disseminated among the ministries, governmental entities and regional administrations. It is also published at the MNREP web-site and publicly available.
MNREP site:
http://www.minpriroda.gov.by/en/new_url_1818395897-en/
Ozone Layer Law's new edition is adopted. The law includes certain statements on HCFC management regulation and control measures strongly supported by the project stakeholders, eg. ban on disposable cylinders for HCFC storing and transportation starting from 2016.
(-) Tajikistan: During the reporting period, the project contributed to the development and adoption of a new legislation including National HCFC phase-out strategy for the period of 2015 – 2020. It simultaneously provided assistance to the development of a number of normative, regulatory documents (Regulations on import/export of ozone depleting substances (ODS), Instructions on allocation of quota for HCFC import) to support the legislation and their submission to key governmental stakeholders for review and further approval. The draft HCFC phase-out strategy is under consideration of the Government for review and endorsement.
(-) Ukraine: Political instability with insititutional changes continued to occur. New national Ozone Focal Point was nominated to work with the GEF/UNDP project. Two (2) missions from legal review and HCFC strategy formulation internationale experts were fielded in May and June 2015 emphasizing the need for Governmental commitment over the HCFC control.
(-) Uzbekistan: Overarching National Programme on Phase-out of ozone-depleting substances (ODS) was developed in 1999 and in 2000 it was adopted by the Resolution of the Cabinet of Ministers #20. More specifically in relation to improvements in HCFC legislation, new regulatory measures to better control of export/import of HCFC and equipment containing HCFC developed, discussed with national partners and submitted by the State Committee for Nature Protection for consideration through organization of national level round table meeting devoted to national and international HCFC phase-out, import/export legislation. Government officials, including representatives from the State Committee for Nature Protection, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Justice, State Customs Committee and other interested national partners involved in discussion of current ODS related regulations and new regulatory measures to be adopted in Uzbekistan. A draft Road Map is planned for development to increase the effectiveness of national legislation related to the HCFC phase-out acceleration.

baseline.comment: ·  Gaps in institutional capacity and HCFC use control system;

target.comment: ·  Effective regulatory instruments to control HCFC use, and thus, import of HCFCs and HCFC containing equipment in place and effectively implemented;

actual.comment:
Since the start of his contract, the following missions have been conducted as part of the international consultant’s contract:
o 2 missions to Tajikistan - regulatory changes accepted in draft new regulations awaiting final approval from the Government
o 2 missions to Belarus - regulatory changes in effect and being enforced
o 2 missions to Ukraine - recomemndations provided; consultations are in process on amending existing regulations)
o 1 mission to Uzbekistan (second one planned for September 2015) - overarching framework exists, improvements are in national consultation process
Each mission was followed by a detailed mission report indicating the recommendations (after the 1st mission in a country); and analysis of whether the recommendations were taken up (during the second mission to a country), and highlighting remaining tasks for each country to cover.
The consultant is also developing, as part of the regional component, a Road Map of implementation of inevitable elements of any HCFC legislation which will help country benchmark their progress against other ones; at the same time, it will allow the project to keep track of the developments in each of the countries through a comparable framework.
Ukraine: draft quota system and draft Ozone legislation developed but not passed the official procedures of adoption due from political instability and management changes in Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources (MENR) of Ukraine.

baseline.comment: ·  Weak HCFC re-use capacity and low-level of technical knowledge and instrumentation to address HCFC in the servicing sector

target.comment: ·  Printed materials on various aspects related to HCFC phase-out (policy control options, enforcement and illegal trade, alternative technologies and energy-efficiency, ODS destruction, best refrigeration practices etc) available

actual.comment:
UNDP continued its cooperation with UNEP to make relevant technical publications available to the countries participating in this project, including in Russian. This includes the most recent technical publications focusing on best practices in refrigeration. Cooperation will be pursued throughout the year, including for translation of the key publications.
Ukraine: in close collaboration with business representatives the investigation on the illegal sales of ODS-containing air-conditioners been conducted. The results of investigation presented to MENR and Custom authorities. As a result the new risk profile for custom data base risk analysis been drafted.

baseline.comment: ·  Limited technical knowledge relating to good refrigeration practices as regards alternative refrigerants (non-ODS/low GWP such as ammonia, carbon dioxide, etc)

target.comment: ·  Current capacities of project stakeholders strengthened through capacity building and investment support in manufacturing and servicing sectors

actual.comment:
In addition to the regional approach of training on refrigeration (see other component), a consultation was held between participating countries on the specificity of the needs for information on low-GWP refrigerants. A cooperation with the EU-funded REAL Alternatives project in order to benefit from the reference training modules under that project has been initiated and will be continued in 2015-2016.
Ukraine: Due to changes in the composition of some GEF assistance recipients (due to military conflict, isntitutional changes or financial situation), the project in Ukraine is undergoing a two-step revision process: (1) initial revision (2015) to cover remaining originally accepted project partners, and (2) deeper revision (2016), in consultations with the GEF, to re-allocate unused funding from manufacturing sector to servicing sector. Therefore, currently planned assistance in the servicing sector is essential to Ukraine in the current circumstances.

baseline.comment: ·  No current information products and programs

target.comment: Information products developed and available

actual.comment: See information above.

baseline.comment: ·  Limited availability of technical tools to test gas composition and quality as well as to limit emissions of HCFCs during equipment maintenance

target.comment: - Four (4) countries have received and are equipped with necessary tools such as multi-gas identifiers to enable better control of HCFC import at the border and minimize illegal trade cases

actual.comment:
Multi-gas analyzers and laboratory equipment has been purchased or in process of procurement as follows:
- Tajikistan: Procurement case for 20 multi-gas analyzers (assocaited protective equipment: gloves, glasses etc) completed, and portable equipment has been supplied to Customs.
- Uzbekistan: 12 advanced and 10 basic multi-gas analyzers are in the process of procurement. Additionally, a special support equipment for existing mass-spectrometer (Shimadzu) to accept gaseous substances (HCFC gases and other mixtures) for analysis is underway.
- Belarus: 12 portable multi-gas analyzers were procured and distributed, and a special mass-spectrometer equipment (Shimadzu) was purchased for the central Customs laboratory to enable precise identificaiton of questionable ODS imports.
- Ukraine: Based on the ongoing initial revision of the project document, the project plans supply of 2 mass-spectrometer equipment for capital (Kiev) and the main port (Odessa) using fast-track procurement procedures based on Belarus's procurement case, and additional portable multi-gas analyzers. Procurement is to start in 2015.

baseline.comment: ·  Limited exposure to alternative technologies and understanding of energy-saving aspects of new modern equipment operational on new technologies

target.comment: Current capacities of project stakeholders strengthened through capacity building and investment support in manufacturing and servicing sectors

actual.comment:
Country representatives were supported to participate in technical meetings on the next generation of refrigerants as well as on energy efficiency benefits in order to be fully included in international-level discussions and benefit from updates on the latest technological developments. The rule for participation in these events has been that, after evaluation of the needs to attend in order to be exposed to new technology or policy information, the participants commit to report to the 4 participating countries on the occasion of subsequent meetings, for the benefit and capacity building of the whole group of countries.
Additionally a delegation of technicians from Belarus were supported to participate in the ChillVenta industry conference in September 2014; and a Tajikistan delegation also participated in the CHINA REFRIGERATION – 2015 organized by China Council for the Promotion of International Trade (CCPIT) and Chinese Association of Refrigeration (CAR) on April 08-10, 2015 in Shanghai.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Regional accelerated phase-out capacity building (all countries)

result.title: Outcome 1 (a)
result.description: Legislative and Policy Options for HCFC phase-out and control

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: ·  Russian language resource materials on HCFC control options prepared

baseline.comment: ·  Key stakeholders generally have limited awareness of the issue or actions required on the higher or technical level to address HCFC phase-out;

target.comment: ·  Availability of key guidance documentation in Russian, or local languages, where required, on HCFC control options, Customs enforcement approaches and methodologies, refrigeration sector capacity building, energy-efficiency, ODS destruction etc;

actual.comment: All relevant publications developed by UNEP as reference materials on Legislation and Policy Options for HCFC phase-out have been reviewed and adapted to the needs of the Non-Article 5 Countries participating in the project. The reviewed texts have been completed as part of the International Consultant’s tasks, and are to be translated.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Awareness training for decision-makers on legislative and regulatory actions accomplished

baseline.comment: ·  Decision-makers from enforcement department (Environment Protection, Customs) have limited knowledge and lack practical skills on the regulatory approaches to effectively control HCFC related challenges;

target.comment: ·  High-level decision-makers of Environment Protection, Customs, territorial inspectorates, other Governmental agencies such as Ministry of Education, Standardization Committee are well informed and support the objectives of HCFC consumption phase-out and measures to address this process;

actual.comment:
Information and experience exchange with other countries in the region and among the target group of countries continued in the reporting period. Delegations from these countries attended thematic meetings of Ozone Officers organized by UNEP DTIE in Tajikistan (October 2014), Belarus (2015), Armenia (May 2015), and in the regional meeting of the current GEF/HCFC project held in Turkey in June 2015.
Technical personnel (from servicing centers) in Belarus and Tajikistan participated in refrigeration technology EXPOs in Germany (2014) and China (2015) respectively by enriching national knowledge and future capacity with current technological developments of direct application in the refrigeratoin and air-conditioning sectors, including on new ODS-free/low GWP technologies.
Further, bilateral visits from more advanced countries of the group were planned, based on special decisionof the regional project board in June 2015, to assist Ukraine with understanding better national project design amd progress achieved in other countries and adapting this experience directly in Ukraine to facilitate implementation of the programme.
All 4 HCFC regulatory instruments were assessed by an international consultant with a view to make sure international expertise benefits to each of the participating countries in their HCFC legislation review and that effective implementation is ensured. The following missions have been conducted as part of the international consultant’s contract (cumulative numbers):
o 2 missions to Tajikistan
o 2 missions to Belarus
o 2 missions to Ukraine
o 1 mission to Uzbekistan (second one planned for September 2015)
Each mission was followed by a detailed mission report indicating the recommendations (after the 1st mission in a country); and analysis of whether the recommendations were taken up (during the second mission to a country), and highlighting remaining tasks.
Awareness-raising of policymakers has been conducted through targeted missions of the international consultant on HCFC legislation, in support of the activities conducted by the national teams on a daily basis with partner Ministries.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: ·  Regional networking on the country with Art 5 and other non Art 5 countries in the region is supported

baseline.comment: ·  Limited number or lack of trained trainers on enforcement and best refrigeration aspects;

target.comment: ·  Training of a selected number of trainers on the technical level (Customs controls and refrigeration practices) is complete on regional level to initiate trainings on national level

actual.comment:
Based on the regional level training of trainers for Customs held in 2014 in Bosnia and Herzegovina, national level trainings were then supported in Belarus (400 officers) and Tajikistan (40 officers) during the reporting period.
Uzbekistan requested additional Customs training in-country which was subsequently planned for September 2015 with help of assigned international expert on HCFC regulatory framework review.
As concerns Ukraine, due to continuing institutional changes, project team was able to agree on cooperation with Customs office only by end of the current reporting period. A bilateral mission was then planned from Customs-Ukraine to Customs-Belarus to exchange experience, and design support to Customs-Ukraine in the most suitable manner to address current needs. Currently, procurement of HCFC gas analytical equipment is initiated by direct procurement based on Belarus's procurement case. Training of Customs officers will be planned in Ukraine during next reporting period by a separate sub-contract with qualified international trainers.

baseline.comment: ·  Required materials in Russian or local languages, on HCFC control options, Customs enforcement approaches and methodologies, refrigeration sector capacity building, energy-efficiency, alternative technologies and their application, illegal trade and PIC, technician certification and ODS waste management related issues are limited in availability or absent;

target.comment: ·  Regional networking with non Art 5 and other Art 5 countries re-established, contacts re-engaged, and overall supports accelerated capacity building of the country as well as essential experience exchange on important HCFC phase-out related topics

actual.comment:
Regional networking continued through participating countries attending UNEP-organized meetings for Ozone Officers from the region (Russian-speaking themathic meetings, and general annual meetings for all Ozone Officers from Balkans, Eastern Europe, Caucasus, Central Asia). These meetings were held in Tajikistan and Belarus in 2014, and Armenia in 2015, with other meetings being planned in 2015 in other countries in the region. Two countries (Belarus -15 representatives; and Tajikistan - 3 representatives) with delegations from the servicing sectors and national Association of refrigeraiton technicians attended respsective EXPOs on new technologies in Germany and China. 3 representatives of Belarus, Uzbekistan and Tajikistan participated in HFC technology workshops in Paris and Bangkok in 2014 and 2015 repsectively.
The following UNEP brochures/publications needed revision to be used by the participating countries which were reviewed and revised for non Art 5 countries (by international consultant, in English versions:
(1) HCFC legislative and policy options
(2) HCFC quota system
(3) Monitoring trade in HCFC
(4) Interpol-UNEP ODS handbook
The following brochures were reviewed but do not need any revision to be used by the participating CEITs:
(1) HCFC risk assessment
(2) HS codes
(3) iPIC
(4) Enforcement strategies of illegal trade in ODS
(5) Customs Training Manual
Customs Training Manual is approaching its full translation into Russian language with help of Tajikistan project (in cooperation with Armenia - Art 5 country funded by MLF fund).

baseline.comment: ·  Regional networking with other partner countries in the region is lacking which prevents information and experience exchange;

target.comment: Regional networking (re- )established

actual.comment:
As of current time, all four (4) project participating countries are linked to the regional cooperation which helps with advancing with national HCFC phase-out plans.
Support to exchange knowledge and experience in HCFC phase-out was continued to be provided during reporting period.
Participating countries attended the following meetings:
- HCFC phase-out implementation challenges meeting, organized by UNEP DTIE for Russian-speaking countries in Dushanbe, Tajikistan in October 2014
- Customs Union and its impacts on HCFC phase-out in the region, organized by UNEP DTIE in Minsk, Belarus in April 2015
- Annual meeting of Ozone Officers from ECA region (Balkans, Eastern Europe, CIS, Turkey, Caucasus and Central Asia) in Yerevan, Armenia in May 2015
- Regional GEF/HCFC project board meeting for Ukraine, Belarus, Uzbekistan and Tajikistan in Istanbul, Turkey in June 2015
These meetings allowed delegations to interact with their colleagues in other countries and extract required knowledge on certain aspects of interesnt in national HCFC phase-out processes.
Cooperation will continue beyond the current project's completion date of March 2016 as the project will request extension for another two (2) years of project implementation timeframe.
This will assist countries in sustaining HCFC phase-out targets in 2015 (90% reduction in HCFC imports and consumption as compared to baseline).

baseline.comment: ·  Cooperation between non-Art 5 countries on effective action standards is minimal or absent.

target.comment: Co-operation (re-)established

actual.comment:
See above.
Such cooperation will continue during the project's lifetime - since March 2016, it is planned to extend the project to two more years of implementation which will be to the benefit of the countries.

result.title: Outcome 1 (b)
result.description: Capacity Building for Enforcement of HCFC control measures by customs and environmental/technical inspection authorities

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: ·  Russian language resource documentation

target.comment: Documentation available

actual.comment:
Customs-related UNEP reference publications were reviewed as part of the International Consultant’s tasks, so that they would be fine-tuned to the needs of the Non-Article 5 Countries funded by the GEF. These edited publications are now available, although consultations are ongoing with UNEP on how to lay them out in an easy to use format (electronic versions).
Tajikistan (in collaboration with Armenia) has taken the lead, with regional component‘s funding, in the translation into Russian of the key document of Customs Training manual, which is about to be completed.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: ·  Awareness raising activities

target.comment: Awareness built

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: ·  Training of Trainers

target.comment: ToT conducted

actual.comment: Based on the delivered trainings in Sarajevo (2014), national trainings were planned and completed in Belarus (400 officers) and Tajikistan (40 officers). Uzbekistan planned a separate specialized (with testing) training in Q3 2015 for 20 trainers. Ukraine, as the project is being revised, will plan for such training only at a later date when required MOUs are concluded with Customs Office for cooperation.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: PIC Network

target.comment: PIC used by countries in the project, facilitating HCFC controls

actual.comment: iPIC is used by the four countries in the project. Two of these four were mentioned as 'Champion countries' in the UNEP publication on iPIC which went out in 2015: The iPIC champions that initiated most queries in 2014 include Belarus [...] Ukraine", demonstrating high awareness and use of this mechanism among participating countries.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: ·  Regional networking

target.comment: Regional networking established

actual.comment:
See above.
Regional networking continued through participating countries attending UNEP-organized meetings for Ozone Officers from the region (Russian-speaking themathic meetings, and general annual meetings for all Ozone Officers from Balkans, Eastern Europe, Caucasus, Central Asia). These meetings were held in Tajikistan and Belarus in 2014, and Armenia in 2015, with other meetings being planned in 2015 in other countries in the region. Two countries (Belarus -15 representatives; and Tajikistan - 3 representatives) with delegations from the servicing sectors and national Association of refrigeraiton technicians attended respsective EXPOs on new technologies in Germany and China. 3 representatives of Belarus, Uzbekistan and Tajikistan participated in HFC technology workshops in Paris and Bangkok in 2014 and 2015 repsectively.

result.title: Outcome 1 (c)
result.description: Capacity Building for the Refrigeration Sector, Incorporation of Energy-Efficiency and GHG reduction elements

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: ·  Preparation of Russian language training manuals and information materials

target.comment: Training Manuals available

actual.comment: Cooperation with UNEP still ongoing on this matter. In addition, a specific specialized awareness raising document was approved as the special issue of a refrigeration publication and will be completed in 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: ·  ToT on Best Refrigeration Practices

target.comment: ToT conducted

actual.comment:
After consultation of all 4 countries, present in the Dushanbe thematic HCFC phase-out meeting in October 2014, it was decided that a joint Regional train-the-trainer meeting for refrigeration technician specialists will be organised in September 2015, through a bidding process with Refrigeration training institutions. The specifics of this training were agreed between countries in Dushanbe.
The bidding process was organised in 2014-2015 and contract has been recently awarded to the Refrigeration Institute - Centro Galileo (Italy). Emphasis was put on the need to share knowledge of the F-Gas regulation ; to allow for information to be provided in Russian ; and the need to obtain certification as an outcome of the training.

result.title: Outcome 1 (d)
result.description: Support for the development of regional institutions, capacity, and cooperation

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: ·  Preparation of Russian language information materials

target.comment: Information materials available

actual.comment: See above

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: ·  Promotion of Information exchange mechanisms

target.comment: Information exchange mechanisms in place

actual.comment:
Since the launch of the project national delegations were sponsored by the regional component of the project to participate in:
o Regional ozone network meetings organised by UNEP for Europe and Central Asia (FYR Macedonia in 2013, Bosnia and Herzegovina in 2014 and Armenia in 2015).
o Thematic meetings organised as part of this UNEP ECA network (for example in Belarus on the new Customs Union and its impact on the MP implementation in 2014 ; HCFC phase-out management plan subregional meetings organised in Kyrgyzstan in 2013 and in Tajiksitan in 2014).
Regarding refrigeration associations, the existing associations were invited to participate in the specific meeting organised in Ohrid in 2013, which initiated collaboration at a regional level and exchange of experiences.
Uzbekistan has prepared and submitted for review and registration documents for establishing such Association in the country (did not exist before). The Association will unite all qualified servicing companies and individual technicians, be one communicaiton channel to the sector on modern developments with best practices on refrigeration equipment maitenance and repairs, and ensure appropriate certification standards in the sector for delivery of quality service to end-user, reduce HCFC leaks by better practices in general in the country, and improve HCFC re-use.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: ·  Facilitation of regional dialogue

target.comment: Regional dialogue established

actual.comment: Overall, as per the objective in the Project Document, it has been possible to re-establish regional networking with non Art 5 and other Art 5 countries and to re-initiate as well essential experience exchange on important HCFC phase-out related topics – which were lacking in the baseline situation.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: HPMP, National Level Capacity Strengthening and HCFC Phase Out Investment

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Formal HCFC Phase-out strategy and action plan developed and endorsed

baseline.comment: ·  No formal HCFC strategy is adopted and enforced through regulatory measures

target.comment: ·  HCFC phase-out strategy fully formulated, packaged as draft legislation for Government approval and cleared by line Ministries/departments for final endorsement

actual.comment:
(-) Belarus; HCFC phase-out strategy is fully formulated, cleared by line Ministries/ departments, adopted and endorsed by the Government (13/03/2013).
(-) Tajikistan: The Committee on Environmental Protection has developed an action plan based on the newly developed HCFC phase-out legislation package. Currently the newly HCFC legislation is submitted to the Government for endorsement.
(-) Ukraine: HCFC data collection has resumed in the reporting period. National HCFC Draft Strategy will be formulated on the basis of such data, and presented to the Government. Recommendations for improving HCFC licensing and quota system and draft Ozone legislation developed but not passed the official procedures of adoption due from political instability and management changes in MENR of Ukraine.
(-) Uzbekistan: Overall Country Programme on ODS phase-out has been in place since 2002, covering HCFC phase-out in general. However, new regulatory measures on better control of export/import of HCFC and equipment containing HCFC were developed, discussed with national partners and submitted by the State Committee for Nature Protection to the Governments consideration through organization of national level round table meeting devoted to national and international HCFC phase-out, import/export legislation.

baseline.comment: ·  Inter-agency coordination to address HCFC phase-out is limited

target.comment: ·  Widely accessible information on HCFC phase-out strategy and its elements

actual.comment:
(-) Belarus: National HCFC phase-out strategy approved in 2013. The relevant information with reference to the source is available in other Internet resources (such as the Legal internet portal www.belta.by; APIMH web site : www.apimh.by etc.
(-) Tajikistan: While developing of a new HCFC legislation inter-agency Task Force has been established. The Inter-agency Task Force members were actively involved during the development and agreement of the documents within each ministries and governmental agencies resulted to final endorsement by the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan.
(-) Ukraine: Project team continues efforts in the area of HCFC strategy formulation. Working level contacts prevail involving Ministry of Natural Resources, Customs and other line Ministries - current political instability does not allow for better progress in current circumstances. EU legislation approximation processes are underway where technical regulations on ODS (HCFC) management are included. Further updates will be provided in future reporting cycles.
(-) Uzbekistan: National partners have familiarized with the National HCFC Phase-out Strategy and Action Plan of Uzbekistan during the inception workshop conducted in September 2014. National Project Coordinator has reported that in Uzbekistan the HCFC Phase-out strategy and corresponding Action Plan, which envisaged phase-out of all groups of ozone depleting substances (Annexes A, B, C and E) were already developed and adopted in 2002. Amendments for improvement have been proposed and are now being discussed in the Government.

baseline.comment: ·  No updated HCFC and HCFC equipment import quota and use system is in place

target.comment: ·  Inter-agency coordination related to HCFC phase-out is improved

actual.comment:
(-) Belarus: National HCFC phaseout strategy is in place, with updated quota system. Due to lack of border within Customs Union, HCFC use control system has been in discussions by conducting interagency meetings and "round table" discussions with involvement of decision-makers from various ministries, non-governmental organizations, private sector, and international organizations. Resulting from such events, the following decisions were made: (i) to prepare recommendations for developing an "roadmap" for adoption of appropriate policies and legislation, as well as mechanisms to monitor the cross-border movement of ODS within and beyond the Customs Union territory; (ii) to prepare an agreement on interagency cooperation in the field of HCFC control between the State Customs Committee (regional customs bodies) and the Ministry of Environment (regional ecological inspections).
(-) Tajikistan: Instructions on allocation of quota for HCFC import to support new HCFC phase-out legislation was developed and endorsed by the chairman of the Committee on Environmental Protection. According to the new HCFC legislation HCFC equipment import quota and use system will be updated in the beginning of each year.
(-) Ukraine: HCFC licensing and quota system is in place, though recommendaitons for removal of exceptions/improvements were not yet adopted. Consultations with Governmental counterparts continue in this respect.
(-) Uzbekistan: Project Board members are involved in discussion on update of ODS import/export control related national legislation, and development of new regulatory measures during national level round table meeting devoted to discussion of national and international HCFC phase-out, import/export legislation.

baseline.comment: ·  Low level of awareness related to HCFC phase-out across stakeholders and general public

target.comment: ·  Effective regulatory measures (quotas etc) are updated and enforced

actual.comment:
(-) Belarus: National legislation on ODS (including HCFCs) management was improved (ref. Law of the Republic of Belarus of June 16, 2014 N 161-W "ABOUT AMENDMENTS AND ADDENDA TO CERTAIN LAWS OF THE REPUBLIC OF BELARUS ON THE OZONE LAYER PROTECTION") by introducing provisions for HCFC import/export control, consumption volumes reduction up to December 31, 2019 in accordance with the MP through introducing license and special permits issuing procedures, ban on production of HCFC and including HCFC containing equipment and HCFC relying technologies into engineering design of new buildings, introducing obligatory reporting on HCFC use and inventory of HCFC containg equipment.
(-) Tajikistan: The awareness raising activities related to HCFC phase-out across stakeholders and general public were conducted during the project implementation.
(-) Ukraine: HCFC licensing and quota system is in place, though recommendaitons for removal of exceptions/improvements were not yet adopted. Consultations with Governmental counterparts continue in this respect.
(-) Uzbekistan: Regulatory measures (allocation of quotas) to effectively control import of ODS, including HCFC and equipment containing HCFC are applied in Uzbekistan. The State Committee for Nature Protection is responsible for the allocation of quotas on ODS import within the framework of quotas for the Republic of Uzbekistan allocated within the Montreal Protocol. Moreover, project will support the Government in study of world’s best practices on import/export control, including quota allocation which will be adopted into the national legislation.

baseline.comment: ·  No current information products and programs

target.comment: ·  Main stakeholders are informed about HCFC phase-out strategy and regulatory measures related to HCFC import and use control

actual.comment:
(-) Belarus: Main stakeholders were regularly informed about HCFC phase-out strategy and regulatory measures related to HCFC import and use control through mass media (1 article was published on Customs Union legislation) and internet resources (2 articles on the national HCFC phase-out strategy and obligations under the MP). Public interest and awareness of the problem was raised through conducting public information campaign on the International Ozone Layer Protection Day.
(-) Tajikistan: While developing HCFC phase-out strategy and regulatory measures, representative of the President Office, senior staff of line ministries and governmental agencies were informed about HCFC import and use control. At the end of consultations and discussions recommendations toward improving inter-agency cooperation and awareness raising among key governmental agencies were provided by respective governmental officials. Apart from that, Civil Society Institutions dealing with environmental protection have actively been participated in awareness raising activities on the ODS use control.
(-) Ukraine: Due to continued political instability, efforts were applied by the project team to discuss the project's objectives with new National ozone Focal point, and within the Ministry of Natural Resources (through meetings and visits of two internationale xperts in 2014 and 2015 - three visits). Awareness on the project and the need for better HCFC import control were discussed during several meetings in the Customs department. National Rada (Parliament) was involved in the discussions on the HCFC control legislation and improvements required in it. Further progress is monitored.
(-) Uzbekistan: About 70 (more than 50% women) key stakeholders – representatives of ministries and agencies, mass media representatives and public/private HCFC users were informed on the HCFC phase-out in Uzbekistan through participating in Inception workshop of the project and in the press-conference devoted to the World Ozone Layer Preservation Day (16 September). Public awareness increased through publication of 15 articles, TV-news and Radio Broadcasts about Ozone layer protection and HCFC phase-out in the mass media, including Internet media. Disseminated posters demonstrating ODS phase out chronology in Uzbekistan.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Trained and equipped working level Customs and enforcement officials, and refrigeration technicians using resources (trainers and training materials) from Component 1 with respect to legislation, regulations, customs controls, refrigeration servicing techniques, and general best practices

baseline.comment: ·  Key Government stakeholders as well as working level officials have limited awareness of HCFC phase-out issue, challenges to address it and skills/tools to enforce HCFC control measures in practice

target.comment: ·  Inclusion of HCFC control issues into curricula of Customs and enforcement officialsâ€™ training institutions

actual.comment:
(-) Belarus: ODS import control issues were included into full- time and distant educational programmes of the Customs Training Institute. More than 400 customs officers were received training in ODS import control issues in 2014.
New study curricula on ODS management was developed and adopted by National Training Center of the Minnature. By 30 June 2015 over passed exams and received an advanced training and specialization certificate on HCFC control methods.
Training programmes, modules and educational materials on ODS management were developed for higher and secondary vocational schools involved into training of refrigeration technicians. As of 2015-2016 academic year the issues on ODS management will be included into curricular of Minsk National Technical University; Mogilev State University of Food Technologies and Polotsk Trade Technological College.
(-) Tajikistan: In close collaboration with Refrigeration Association, introductory sessions on the use of ODS equipment and other specialized equipment were carried out for 40 customs officers. The GEF/UNDP project has provided the Customs Agency with 23 necessary equipment on identification of ODS at the customs entry points. Moreover, the Customs Service has been equipped with ODS mobile laboratory.
(-) Ukraine: Relations developed with State Fiscal Service (Custom). Primary order for training needs and equipment supply obtained from Custom. Study visit of Custom’s representatives is scheduled for August-September 2015 to Belarus colleagues on different aspects of training and ODS-detecting equipment use.
With Project provided support, the Custom’s Risk Analysis Data Base expanded on the air-conditioners (ODS-containing equipment with refrigerant R22). Additional check of air-conditioners is obligatory to avoid illegal import of ODS-containing equipment.
On 22-24 April, 2015 the Project participated and contributed to the Annual Ecological Forum in Kiev, where the Project advertised and presented among key counterparts, governmental authorities, NGOs and business.
Further actions on agenda - to assist in the participation/preparation of Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources representatives in the next ExCom in September 2015 and supply ODS-detecting equipment to the Custom.
(-) Uzbekistan:Training curricula on customs officers’ issues related to new developments in the area of HCFC and HCFC-based equipment import control measures/procedures for training 20 trainers from the State Customs Committee and for further training 300 customs and enforcement officials developed.
Completion of training module on customs officers’ issues related to new developments in the area of HCFC and HCFC-based equipment import control measures/procedures for training 300 customs and enforcement officials, as well as conduction of training activities is expected to be implement in the next 2015/2016 reporting period.

baseline.comment: ·  Limited active educational efforts or tools are available

target.comment: ·  Update of study plans specialized training centers (enforcement inspectors, technicians)

actual.comment:
(-) Belarus: Teaching and Methodological complex (TMC) aimed at development of practical skills to repair and service refrigeration equipment was developed and transferred to APIMH for organizing advanced trainings with subsequent issuing of a Certificate. The education will start in the latter half of Year 2015.
(-) Tajikistan: A training programme for Customs Officers was developed and adapted based on the UNEP Customs Manual. The National Customs Training Programme has been approved by the Customs Service and three-day trainings are being conducted for 120 customs officers in the Customs Retraining Institute. In accordance with the signed MoU with Customs Service, the Customs Service has been providing spaces and necessary support to strengthen the capacity of officers.
(-) Ukraine: see above
(-) Uzbekistan: Draft training module on adequate use of HCFC re-use equipment and best refrigeration practices in maintenance and retrofits developed by the involvement of specialist of Tashkent State Technical University for further training at least 800 refrigeration technicians. New alternative non-ODS technologies using such natural refrigerants as ammonia, carbon dioxide and propane introduced into the draft training module. 200 technicians will be trained during October-November 2015 and 600 in January-March 2016.

baseline.comment: ·  Illegal trade in ODS continues unregistered and unnoticed

target.comment: ·  Well informed stakeholder community engaged in addressing HCFC phase-out issue with required level of understanding and technical capacity

actual.comment:
(-) Belarus: Customs laboratory is fully equipped with sophisticated Shimadzu mass-spectrometer, and additional portable multi-gas analyzers were distributed to important Customs stations to screen HCFC/HFC gas cyllinders. No cases of illegal trade in Belarus have been registered during the reporting period.
(-) Tajikistan: Project initiated joint monitoring of illegal trade/import of ODS by the Customs Service and the Committee on Environmental Protection. As a result of joint monitoring, 6 cases of illegal trade of unwanted ODS were registered in 2014. Furthermore, Customs Service caught 150 kg of HCFCs at a Customs entry point where no permits for HCFC import were identified as available. As a result, violators were fined in amount of USD 820. And also explanatory works among ODS traders/importers were carried out by the NOU at the markets and shops during the reporting period.
(-) Ukraine: Capacity of State Customs Committee on better control of illegal import of HCFC will be improved through equipping Customs control posts with analytical equipment for which procurement process is starting; Bilateral meetings/visits are planned to other countries of the project for experience exchange and use of this experience in Ukraine to facilitate project implementation progress.
(-) Uzbekistan: Capacity of State Customs Committee on better control of illegal import of HCFC will be improved through equipping Custom control posts with analytical equipment for which procurement process started. Specialized trainings are planned by the project in 2015 for trainers who will in future build capacities of other Customs officers.

baseline.comment: ·  No current information products and programs

target.comment: ·  Re-tooling (basic portable analytical and instrumentation for servicing sector) of main stakeholder groups implemented

actual.comment:
(-) Belarus: Customs points and regional environmental inspectorates were equipped with portable tools for chemical analysis of HCFC (multi-gas analyzers). These tools were procured for the Customs services (4 items), ecological inspections (6 items) and training institutions (2). Moreover, a chromatography-mass spectrometer was purchased for the Customs's laboratory for high-quality content examination of the goods containing ODS when they are crossing the state border, and legal review issues come up. In order to meet the needs of re-tooling servicing sector 27 items of specialized instruments and equipment were purchased and transferred to the ownership of APIMH (Refrigeration Association) for further distribution among educational institutions and service centers.
(-) Tajikistan: International bidding process was conducted and HCFC re-use equipment and tools have been procured and delivered to the training centres and refrigeration technicians.
(-) Ukraine: Initially, only training in best refrigeration practices was originally foreseen in this project as it was more geared towards formulation of the HCFC phase-out strategy (an element which was not complete from a preceeding GEF/MSP programme) and based on data findings in the serivicing sector it was planned to formulate second project concept to provide assistance to the servicing sector. Nonetheless, due to political changes, armed conflict and financial slowdown in Ukraine, majority of GEF assistance recipients in the manufacturing sector either were isolated in the area of armed conflict or went bankrupt, and it was decided in consultations to re-phase the unused funding in two-step budget revision with initial assistance to be provided to demo projects (only) in the servicing sector. Once revisions are approved, assistance will be given to procure recovery and recycling tools to one service center in Ukraine for pilot demonstration.
(-) Uzbekistan: Needs of the State Customs Committee, as well as instructors of environmental agencies on portable analytical equipment and tools for the identification of ODS, including HCFC and other ozone friendly substances identified. Custom control posts and environmental officers will be equipped with 12 advanced and 9 basic ODS identifiers.
