Technical specification of 125 set modern equipment and tools to better service refrigeration and air conditioning equipment completed for equipping at least 100 public and private enterprises – HCFC users. Procurement of analytical and service equipment is underway. Criteria for selection of public and private enterprises of the refrigeration and air conditioning sector agreed and selection of pilot enterprises started.

baseline.comment: ·  Lack of portable HCFC analytical equipment and skills to control end use and illegal imports

target.comment: ·  Illegal trade is registered and stopped at entry points

actual.comment:
(-) Belarus: No cases of illegal trade of ODS were registered in 2014.
(-) Tajikistan: The procured equipment for refrigeration technicians and customs officers includes portable HCFC analytical equipment and ODS mobile lab to prevent illegal imports of HCFCs.
(-) Ukraine: Capacity of State Customs Committee on better control of illegal import of HCFC will be improved through equipping custom control posts with analytical equipment for which procurement process is starting.
(-) Uzbekistan: Capacity of State Customs Committee on better control of illegal import of HCFC will be improved through equipping custom control posts with analytical equipment for which procurement started. Custom control posts and environmental officers will be equipped with 12 advanced and 9 basic ODS identifiers. As per information from the State Customs Committee, in August 2014 7568 kg illegally imported refrigerants (R404, R134a, R22, R12, R404a, R407c) confiscated from which 136 kg R12, which import to Uzbekistan prohibited.

baseline.comment: ·  General absence of basic servicing tools to strengthen HCFC re-use system (not applicable to Ukraine)

target.comment: - Servicing tools to support HCFC re-use procured and distributed for daily applicaiton in the servicing sector.

actual.comment:
See information above on the supply of equipment in each of the countries. Procurement processes are either complete/near completion (Belarus, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan), in immediate plans based on pending project revision (Ukraine).
It is to be noted that as Ukraine is adapting its strategy to possibly cover the servicing sector, it may benefit in the future of the experience of the other 3 countries.

indicator.title: Indicator 13
indicator.description: Targeted HCFC Phase-out Investment Program and Demonstration projects (Belarus)

target.comment: described in sections below

actual.comment: Described in the sections below.

indicator.title: Indicator 14
indicator.description: Implementation of a foam conversion project at MAZ Kupava

baseline.comment: MAZ-Kupava (foam product manufacturer) depends on HCFC-141b in manufacturing processes;

target.comment: ·  MAZ-Kupava technologically converted to non-ODS/ low GWP technology (HCFC-141b based polyols to c-pentane)

actual.comment:
Based on additional consultations with MAZ-Kupava, project team and international expert, it was decided to agree to have one consolidated ITB for both foaming and press (with mold) lines whereas MAZ-Kupava would be responsible to cover excess costs above GEF budget for this sub-component.
During bidding it was discovered that the foaming line costs from EU based providers with regional service representation (Cannon-Afros) exceeded the GEF budget, and project team had long negotiations with MAZ-Kupava to agree on co-funding this extra cost.
MAZ-Kupava, upon agreement, applied to special Governmental funds for additional support to ensure the company's PU line is fully modernized. Decision to fund MAZ-Kupava was cleared end of June 2015.
UNDP-led consolidated tender (both lines were a part of one ITB to ensure compatibility) then triggered assembly of both lines with delivery, installation and commissioning of the equipment scheduled for Q1, 2016. MAZ-Kupava will directly release extra funding to Cannon-Afros in the second half of 2015 when funds from the Government are in place.
Delay in implementing this pilot caused by difficult financial situation occurred in the country in the end of 2014 and as a result, funding gap of MAZ Kupava to fulfill its obligations for procurement the remaining part of non-ODS/low GWP technological line.

baseline.comment: ·  Alternative technologies are scarcely available to the company for access and transfer, not tested at the facility and lack processing and safety instrumentation for practical introduction

target.comment: ·  HCFC use at MAZ Kupava stopped and company committed not to use HCFCs any longer

actual.comment:
See remark above on the delays experienced with this component.
Once equipment is installed early 2016, commisioned with trials and then normal production, and safety audits are completed, equipment will be handed-over to MAZ-Kupava, and HCFC use will stop.
MAZ-Kupava will sign a commitment letter to stop use of HCFC-141b, and old line will be dismantled in order not to be used elswhere as second-hand equipment.

baseline.comment: ·  Refrigerated trucks with foam insulation continue to be manufactured with the use of HCFCs

target.comment: ·  Technical staff is knowledgeable on correct use of new technology

actual.comment: Cannon-Afros will ensure, as the technology supplier, to install and commission this equipment, which will be followed by training to MAZ-Kupava's staff.

indicator.title: Indicator 17
indicator.description: Implementation of a solvent conversion project at David Gorodok Electromechanical Plant

baseline.comment: ·  Atlant/David-Gorodok (solvent users) depends on HCFC-141b in manufacturing processes and this is a high emissive use of HCFCs;

target.comment: ·  Atlant/David-Gorodok technologically converted to non-ODS technology (HCFC-141b to transblends based on HFCs closed loop cycle and minimization of agent use reduce emissions)

actual.comment:
During reporting period, project made a market research on existing solvent-based, closed-cycled (with solvent recuperation) washing unit. ITB completed, and contracts on supply of the equipment required for technological conversion to non-ODS cleaning process at David Gorodok Electromechanical Plant were signed. This was preceeded by a technical visit to the selected supplier in June 2015 near Istanbul, Turkey on the margins of the regional project board meeting.
Supply, installation, commissioning of the equipment as well as personnel training is scheduled for 3rd quarter of 2015. This will be accompanied by a final visit with inspection and safety audit from the assigned international expert. Recommendations from safety audit will be submitted to David-Gorodok company.
The choice of a solvent to replace curent HCFC use was Hladis ACX (consisting of methylene chloride - R30 - and additives). Since being subject to emission contorl standards, related GOSTs on ventilation and ambient air (GOST 12.4.021 and 12.1.005) will need to be followed. It is understood that ventilation system was ready to be installed by David-Gorodok.

baseline.comment: ·  Alternative technologies are scarcely available to the company for access and transfer, not tested at the facility and lack processing and safety instrumentation for practical introduction

target.comment: ·  HCFC use at Atlant/David-Gorodok stopped and company committed not to use HCFCs any longer

actual.comment: Once equipment is installed and commissioned, David-Gorodok will sign a commitment letter to avoid using HCFCs in their solvent washing operations.

baseline.comment: ·  Spares (compressors and others) for refrigerators continue to be manufactured with the use of HCFCs as degreasing agent

target.comment: ·  Technical staff is knowledgeable on correct use of new technology

actual.comment:
Current practices at David-Gorodok related to open air usage of HCFCs in solvent-washing, and the equipment that will be supplied to the company is of closed cycle with solvent recuperation.
Safety audit will be provided by assigned international expert after equipment has been installed in 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 20
indicator.description: Demonstration of benefits of natural cooling in one or two sectors such as agricultural milk coolers

baseline.comment: ·  Limited proliferation of low GWP alternatives (NH3, CO2 double stage, HCs etc) to HCFCs in refrigerated equipment;

target.comment: ·  Non-ODS/low-zero GWP (NH3, CO2 double stage, HCs etc) technologies in the servicing sector demonstrated and promoted through awareness raising;

actual.comment:
National experts conducted analysis of the internationally recognized advanced cooling technologies. As a result, three directions for introducing non-ODS/low GWP technologies (ammonia - NH3, carbon dioxide - CO2, propane - R290) were considered to be the most prospective ones for the economy of Belarus.
Information on prospects for use climate-friendly technologies in cold industry was published in the specialized magazine for refrigeration sector "Microclimate and cold».
The pilot project to demonstrate the advantages of using natural refrigerant (ammonia) in modern air-conditioning systems has been started. Implementation of this demonstration project will benefit country by providing assistance to pilot assembly of new ammonia (NH3) refrigeration systems.

baseline.comment: ·  Safety standards for new low GWP alternatives do not exist

target.comment: ·  Stakeholder community (private/public HCFC equipment user sector) well informed about new alternative technologies and their benefits;

actual.comment:
See description above.
Stakeholder community (private/public HCFC equipment user sector, educational institutions, policy makers, etc.) was well informed about new alternative technologies and their benefits by presenting the analysis results at the round-table discussion with participation of over 20 members (November 2014) and at the meeting of Project Coordinative Board (December 2014).

baseline.comment: ·  Generally low awareness on new alternative technologies in the servicing sector and benefits in energy savings (co-benefits for economic operations as well as for climate change);

target.comment: ·  Local engineering companies gain knowledge and skills to assemble and operate such technologies in future;

actual.comment:
As a part of the project, local engineering company “Myasomolmontazh” will gain knowledge and skills to assemble and operate such technologies in future.
Currently, the contract for the project design works has concluded. Delivery, installation and commissioning of the equipment is scheduled for Q1, 2016.

baseline.comment: ·  No current information products and programs;

target.comment: ·  Safety standards for new alternatives reviewed and adopted;

actual.comment: Activities planned in future reporting cycles.

baseline.comment: ·  Lack of experience with, knowledge of and skills to assemble, install, operate and maintain HCFC-free commercial/industrial equipment using non-ODS/low-zero GWP technologies;

target.comment: ·  Performance of new equipment is regularly recorded;

actual.comment: Activities planned in future reporting cycles.

baseline.comment: ·  Low readiness for/acceptance of new technologies by end-users.

target.comment: ·  Market is more prepared for the acceptance of new alternatives.

actual.comment:
It is expected that with practical introduction of newer non-ODS/low GWP technologies, the market will be more ready to uptake these in future once local capacity to manage such technology has been improved.
Additional reporting is expected in future reporting cycles.

indicator.title: Indicator 26
indicator.description: Upgrade of HCFC re-use system through strengthening R/R/R centers and improving local distribution of bulk HCFC/HFCs in support of container import regulations

baseline.comment: ·  HCFCs are not re-used domestically lack of a comprehensive HCFC re-use system, and country depends on imports

target.comment: ·  Regulatory measures to ban single use containers are effected and allow to create HCFC distribution system in country;

actual.comment:
Legislative provisions to ban import/export and use of non-refillable containers were introduced in 2014 (ref to the Law of the Republic of Belarus of June 16, 2014 N 161-W "About Amendments and Addenda to certain Laws of the Republic of Belarus on the Ozone Layer Protection").
This is seen as an important factor in future to help established in-country HCFC distribution system where chemicals in bulk are imported (larger 500 kg or 1 ton capacity cylinders) which are easy to check by Customs, and the spread of single-use cillynders which remain with unevacuated fractions of HCFCs and are considered waste would be gradually stopped.
This also will provide additional business opportunities on HCFC distribution in the country, and potentially in the region in long-term perspective if business takes off well and becomes a regional hub.

baseline.comment: ·  HCFC re-cycling and reclaim equipment, or network, is generally outdated and not suited for HCFCs in the former case and is absent in the latter

target.comment: ·  HCFC re-use system upgraded through strengthening R/R/R centers countryâ€™s technical capacity is improved;

actual.comment:
National scheme of collection and re-use of HCFCs in the country with the list of service centers and their functions in recycling and recovery of HCFCs, as well as a network of regional centers, which can carry out the primary collection, sorting and transport of HCFC-containing products was developed and approved by MNREP.
Four (4) service centers ("Holodon», "Torgtekhnika», "Laminar», "Hladagentservis») and APIMH (Refrigeration Association) have confirmed their interest and willingness to participate in implementation of the HCFC re-use scheme.
Information was presented at a meeting with the participation of 20 representatives of interested organizations and enterprises in the format of "round table", 4 December 2014 and at a meeting of the Steering Board of the project December 23, 2014.
The needs of service centers for Recovery/Recylcing/Reclaim/service tools and equipment for ensuring their capacity to fulfil whole R/R/R cycle of HCFCs have been identified.
Equipment will be purchased by the end of 2015, and distributed to participants of this sub-component.

baseline.comment: ·  Analytical equipment for servicing sector does not exist to ensure quality of re-cycled/reclaimed HCFC refrigerants and improve confidence of buyers (servicing centers/technicians or end-users)

target.comment: ·  HCFC re-use system is implemented in practice allowing to reduce dependence on import of HCFCs;

actual.comment:
Please see description above. Activities in this sub-component have started in the reporting period.
Additional progress/updates will be provided in future reporting cycles.

baseline.comment: ·  Limited active educational efforts or tools on best refrigeration servicing practices are available

target.comment: ·  Technical center staff is trained on adequate use of equipment and best refrigeration practices in equipment maintenance and retrofits;

actual.comment: Technical staff of the service centers will be trained on adequate use of equipment and best refrigeration practices in equipment maintenance and retrofit during a package of advanced trainings organized by APIMH.

target.comment: ·  Well informed stakeholder community engaged in addressing HCFC phase-out issue with required level of understanding and technical capacity.

actual.comment:
Please see description above.
Preliminary consultations on planning re-tooling of the service centers in Belarus have started in the reporting period.
Additional progress/updates in this part will be provided in future reporting cycles on the degree on engagement of the refrigeration/AC equipment servicing sector.

indicator.title: Indicator 31
indicator.description: Pilot unwanted ODS Destruction Project

baseline.comment: ·  Gradual accumulation of obsolete ODS waste (unusable mixtures and emptied HCFC cylinders with ODS fractions) and the acute need to dispose of such wastes;

target.comment: ·  Small-scale obsolete ODS destruction capacity established on a pilot basis to re-enforce the HCFC re-use system and a planned ban on single use containers;

actual.comment:
Analysis of the international market proposals for low capacity destruction units, their cost effectiveness (operational expenses are very high) and the perspectives of introducing them into the national R/R/R scheme (Government considers establishing a special chlorinated waste destruction technology that would then be able to accept waste ODS gases which area also chlorinated) resulted in refusal of MNREP to acquire such kind of equipment, and this led to cancellation of the international tender results. Actual amount of registered waste is 300 kg which is small amount that does not justify establishing a unit like this.
This issue was discussed at the project board in May 2015, and it was decided to re-allocate these funds for implementation of pilot projects introducing non-ODS/low GWP cooling technologies.
The issue of the most effective way to utilize non-reusable HCFCs is still under consideration in the Government. Since the geographical position of Belarus allows for export of such wastes to EU-based qualified high-temperature incinerators (HTI) this will be one of possibilities in future once ODS waste gas levels achieve larger manageable volumes.

baseline.comment: ·  Only prototype laboratory equipment on hazardous waste processing exists with no emission controls in place;

target.comment: ·  Staff trained to operate and maintain equipment;

actual.comment: Activity cancelled due to high operational costs of researched

baseline.comment: ·  Small quantities of obsolete ODS waste to generate interest for export to major hazardous waste destruction sites

target.comment: ·  Stockpiles of obsolete ODS destroyed by supplied technology;

actual.comment: Please see description above.

baseline.comment: ·  Lack of integration of ODS disposal into HCFC re-use system to complete ODS management cycle

target.comment: ·  Country is fully equipped to handle full-cycle of ODS management with demonstration element;

actual.comment: Please see description above.

baseline.comment: ·  Generally lack of appropriate ODS destruction experience in Central Asia region

target.comment: Dissemination of results performed on the regional scale.

actual.comment: Please see description above.

indicator.title: Indicator 36
indicator.description: Targeted HCFC Phase-out Investment Program and Demonstration projects (Tajikistan)

target.comment: Description provided in sections below

indicator.title: Indicator 37
indicator.description: Demonstration of End-users Grants for retrofits/ replacements

baseline.comment: · Alternative technologies are not commonly used for retrofit of existing systems and are not field tested to facilitate practical introduction

target.comment: · Demonstrated benefits of up to date modern cooling equipment

actual.comment:
The preliminary list of equipment for implementation of demo projects on retrofit is prepared.
Meetings with potential partners on demo projects are conducted and few facilities identified for application of demo projects in Tajikistan.
As a result, a few social (orphanage and nursing home) and commercial structures were identified to install replacements. The bidding process to identify potential partner to deliver replacement equipment is underway.

baseline.comment: · Refrigerated equipment in poor condition continues to be serviced with the use of HCFCs and maintained by the companies in these sectors

target.comment: · Awareness of the wider community of HCFC users raised regarding such solutions

actual.comment:
The poor conditions of refrigeration equipment and its maintenance was taken into consideration while developing solicitation documents on procurement of special equipment for refrigeration experts.
International Bidding Process was organized by the project and services companies were provided with modern equipment such as advanced refrigerant analyzer/identifiers, E-weighting scales; Refrigeration tools to improve the servicing sector.

baseline.comment: · No or minimal investment is taking place to retrofit or replace HCFC equipment with alternative refrigerant systems

target.comment: · Reduced knowledge barriers towards equipment retrofits/conversions

actual.comment:
Demonstration projects to replace HCFC equipment with alternative refrigerant systems will be started at the end of 2015.
At the moment, a few social and commercial facilities were identified. The social facilities are being offered by the Ministry of Education and Ministry of Labor as their contribution to the project. Letters of support are available. And also, a private sector has been investing to replace its equipment with alternative refrigeration and seeking project support to procure part of the equipment.
The in-kind contribution of project partners are estimated to USD 100,000.

baseline.comment: · No or minimal information is available on opportunities to reduce dependence to HCFC

target.comment: · Accelerated retirement of HCFC-based equipment and HCFC use in this sector decreased

actual.comment:
In 2013-2014, the ratio of imported HCFC-based equipment and alternative refrigerants were as follow: HCFC-based equipment - approximately 53% and alternative refrigerants - approximately 47%.
In 2014-2015, the ratio of imported HCFC-based equipment and alternative refrigerants are as follow: HCFC-based equipment - approximately 32% (decreasing) and alternative refrigerants - approximately 68% (increasing) though the total number of imported equipment in 2014-2015 has been decreased to 12%.
This indicates that there is a shift in the import trends, and bank of HCFC-based equipment in the country will gradually stop growing, and this will reduce pressure on the need for virgin HCFCs in import to service this equipment in future.

target.comment: · Technical staff is knowledgeable on correct use of new technologies and equipped with basic servicing instrumentation to ensure equipment servicing as per standard international practices

actual.comment:
As part of the regional component (described above), UNDP Tajikistan has led bidding process to identify International Training Institution to provide certified trainings for refrigeration experts from all targeted CEIT countries. As a result, Italian training institution Centro Galileo was identified and contracted by UNDP.
It is expected to conduct international international certification training in the beginning of September 2015. All four (4) countries will nominate representatives of the servicing sector in each to participate and get international certification to allow training locally to a wider number of technicians and service centers.

indicator.title: Indicator 42
indicator.description: Demonstration of benefits for natural cooling

baseline.comment: · Limited proliferation of alternatives to HCFCs in refrigerated equipment

target.comment: · Natural cooling low-zero ODS/low-zero GWP technologies in the servicing sector demonstrated and promoted

actual.comment:
The bidding process to procure and deliver equipment for application of natural cooling technologies was initiated and potential national company was contracted by the project. 15 packages with natural cooling technology will be purchased in 2015/2016 and installed for demonstration and effectiveness monitoring. If succesful, energy-efficiency gains are possible, and this project can be replicated elswhere.
During the reporting period, after technical research and negotiations with the private sector, the project team conducted number of meetings with cellular companies such as Babilon-mobile, T-Cell and Megafone to start arrangements with implementation of demo projects on natural cooling. As a result, co-financing letters from the companies to provide their facilities for demo projects were received.
It is expected to start demonstration projects at the end of 2015.

baseline.comment: · Safety standards for new alternatives do not exist

target.comment: · Stakeholder community (private/public HCFC equipment user sector) well informed about new alternative technologies and their benefits

actual.comment:
During conducting capacity building trainings for refrigeration technicians and national workshops, more than 300 people including representatives of private and public sectors (service companies) have been informed about new alternative technologies.
The benefits of alternative technologies were demonstrated during practical sessions carried out in the Refrigeration Association.

baseline.comment: · Generally low awareness on new alternative technologies in the servicing sector and benefits in energy savings (co-benefits for economic operations as well as for climate change)

target.comment: · Local engineering companies gain knowledge and skills to assemble and operate such technologies in future

actual.comment: As reported above, in the course of refresher courses for 300 refrigeration technician and dealers of equipment, the economic benefits of energy savings and new alternative technologies with low GWP and natural refrigeration in the servicing sector were discussed and demonstrated.

baseline.comment: · No current information on products and programs demonstrating natural cooling technologies

target.comment: · Safety standards for new alternatives reviewed and adopted

actual.comment:
The GEF/UNDP Project has been actively collaborating with TajikStandard to review and adopt safety standards for new alternatives.
The terms and conditions of imported products subject to mandatory certification, provide a certificate of conformity certifying the quality and safety of products. International certificates of conformity for products is recognized by the Republic of Tajikistan in accordance with international and inter-state agreements. On the basis of such agreements by the certification body a recognition document is issued that are valid along with the certificate of conformity of the Republic of Tajikistan.

baseline.comment: · Lack of experience with, knowledge of and skills to assemble, install, operate and maintain HCFC-free commercial/industrial equipment using non-ODS/low-zero GWP technologies (NH3, CO2 double stage, HCs etc)

target.comment: · Performance/operational parameter comparison of old Vs. new equipment monitored and available

actual.comment: During the reporting period, the project team has learned performance/operational parameters of R-410 in winter period. It has been revealed that efficiency of R-410 is higher in outdoor minus temperature than R-22. This helps in implementation of alternative technologies and energy saving projects related to natural cooling technologies.

baseline.comment: · Low readiness for/acceptance of new technologies by users

target.comment: · Market is more prepared for the acceptance of new alternatives

actual.comment: As a result of assessments it has been identified that the price of identical equipment based on alternative refrigerants and HCFCs have a little differences (15-20%). Consequently, the local market is ready to accept equipment working on alternative refrigerants.

indicator.title: Indicator 48
indicator.description: Upgrades of HCFC re-use system

baseline.comment: · No active network to facilitate reuse of HCFC lack of a comprehensive HCFC re-use system, these are not re-used domestically and country depends on imports

target.comment: · HCFC re-use system upgraded through strengthening of Refrigeration Association and R/R/R centers across the country in strategic locations countryâ€™s technical capacity is improved

actual.comment:
In 2014, the Refrigeration Association was provided with ODS equipment. During the reporting period, the project facilitated establishment of four R/R/R centers in four regions of the country.
The R/R/R centers were also equipped (4 sets of modern R/R equipment from STAG-Spain - 3 recycling and 1 reclaim machines, including supplementary HCFC recovery and equipment servicing equipment: reusable recovery cylliners, tools, leak detectors, etc) and the staff were trained by the experts of the Refrigeration Association.
As for basic equipment (tools) sets for smaller servicing companies and individual technicians, around 60 recovery machines (with supplementary equipment) and up to 100 sets of refrigeration tools were procured for delivery.
Another key result is increasing number of members of the Association due to their willingness to attend the refrigeration trainings and receiving certificates. As per new HCFC legislation, the Refrigeration Association will be part of the institute to certify refrigeration experts in order to obtain ODS licence from the Committee on Environmental Protection.

baseline.comment: · No proactive Refrigeration Technicians Association - Association does not have mandate to demonstrate mechanism to recover and distribute purified HCFC

target.comment: · HCFC re-use system is implemented in practice allowing to reduce dependence on import of HCFCs

actual.comment:
Thanks to project interventions, implementation of HCFC re-use system allowed to decrease import of HCFCs to 12% in the country.
It is expected to continue collaboration with Refrigeration Association and decrease HCFC import up to 30% by the end of the project.

baseline.comment: · HCFC re-cycling and reclaim equipment, or network, is generally outdated and not suited for HCFCs in the former case and is absent in the latter

target.comment: · Technical service center staff is trained on adequate use of equipment and best refrigeration practices in equipment maintenance and retrofits

actual.comment:
During the reporting period technical staff of the centers were trained by the National Capacity Building Consultant on the on adequate use of equipment and best refrigeration practices.
Moreover, once the sessions of the refresher course which was conducted for 300 technicians is related to the maintenance of the equipment, best refrigeration practices as well as use of modern equipment.

baseline.comment: · Analytical equipment for servicing sector does not exist to ensure quality of re-cycled/reclaimed HCFC refrigerants and confidence of buyers

target.comment: · Well informed stakeholder community engaged in addressing HCFC phase-out issue with required level of understanding and technical capacity

actual.comment:
As reported earlier, all service centers were equipped with necessary equipment such as gas analyzers/identifiers.
The bidding process to procure and deliver ODS recycling and reclaiming equipment is completed.

baseline.comment: · Limited active educational efforts or tools are available

actual.comment:
The project provided significant support in the development and endorsement of curricula for technicians of refrigerant and air-conditioning systems. In close collaboration with the Ministry of labor, migration and employment of Tajikistan, the Engineering – Pedagogical College of Dushanbe and Refrigeration Association more than 300 refrigeration technicians passed five-day refresher courses on the service delivery best practices of refrigeration equipment and air-conditioning systems’, recycling, recovery and re-use of ODS (HCFCs)". The theory part of the courses took place at the Engineering – Pedagogical College and practical sessions on the use of ODS alternative equipment at the Refrigeration Association.
A Memorandum of Understanding between the College and Association was also signed by parties. It is also ensured that the College will initiate a new short-term (six-months) training programme for young technicians on refrigeration and air-conditioning and further integrate into the professional education system of the College. This is a new specialization that will be endorsed by the Ministry of labour, migration and employment of the Republic of Tajikistan.

indicator.title: Indicator 53
indicator.description: Targeted HCFC Phase-out Investment Program and Demonstration projects (Uzbekistan)

target.comment: Description provided in sections below

indicator.title: Indicator 54
indicator.description: Technical Assistance AZN Techno

baseline.comment: · The only organized and economically stable refrigerated equipment manufacturer in country depends on HCFCs in manufacturing processes

target.comment: · AZN Techno technologically converted to non-ODS technologies (HCFC-141b polyols to water-based technology and HCFC-22 to HFCs for commercial refrigeration equipment)

actual.comment:
With recruitment of project manager in July 2014, and inception workshop in September 2014, joint plan of cooperation between the project and company "AZN Techno" was developed.
As stated (planned) at the project formulation stage, AZN Techno foaming technology (used in insulation of commercial refrigeration stands) was converted from use of HCFC-141b to water-based (non-ODS, non-GWP) solutions with guidance from its poliol supplier based in the Russian Federation (Vladipur system house). Company invested approximately US$ 92,000 for this activity.
As AZN Techno also uses HCFC-22 for charging its commercial trade equipment, the project has assisted the company with purchase of HFC-404a charging station (this refrigerant blend being used in commercial sector) to replace the current use of HCFC-22. Additional thermal imaging equipment was procured and supplied to AZN to help with leak-proofing manufactured products.
Additional consultations are planned with the company to continue to help with complementary equipment/training to ensure sustainability of current assistance round.

baseline.comment: · Alternative technologies are scarcely available for access and transfer, not tested and lack instrumentation for practical introduction

target.comment: · HCFC use at AZN Techno stopped and company committed not to use HCFCs any longer

actual.comment:
See information above.
AZN Techno has self-converted to water-based technology for foaming of its commercial refrigeration equipment, and its HCFC-22 charging operations have been replaced with HFC-404a technology.
Once complementary equipment/training is provided, this sub-component will be considered complete, and project completion report will be prepared to indicate stop of use of HCFCs at the enterprise.

baseline.comment: · Refrigerated equipment continues to be manufactured and maintained by the company with the use of HCFCs

target.comment: · Technical staff is knowledgeable on correct use of new technologies and equipped with basic servicing instrumentation to ensure equipment servicing as per allowed international practices

actual.comment: Needs of company on trainings identified and organization of trainings for technical staff on capacity development planned within the join work plan.

indicator.title: Indicator 57
indicator.description: Demonstration and replacement programme for the refrigeration sector

baseline.comment: · Limited proliferation of alternatives to HCFCs in refrigerated equipment

target.comment: · Non-ODS/low-zero GWP (ammonia, CO2, HCs) technologies in the servicing sector demonstrated and promoted

actual.comment:
Needs assessment on application of alternative and energy efficient non-ODS/low-zero GWP (ammonia, CO2, HCs) technologies conducted.
Announcement of national contest of project proposals for implementation of demonstration projects initiated, and call for proposal was placed in local mass media.
As a result, six (6) project proposals from HCFC users and refrigeration equipment manufacturers collected and evaluation is underway.
Implementation of demonstration projects expected to start in the next 2015/2016 reporting period.

baseline.comment: · Safety standards for new alternatives do not exist

target.comment: · Stakeholder community (private/public HCFC equipment user sector) well informed about new alternative technologies and their benefits

actual.comment:
In order to support evaluation of existing safety standards applied in Uzbekistan and other countries, namely EU standards, as well as for development of proposals on use of safety standards for new non-ODS/low GWP technologies, project recruited international consultant on alternative ODS-free/low GWP technologies.
International consultant will also support the project in implementation of demonstration projects and development of guidelines on application of new ozone friendly technologies. Draft guidelines (manual) on energy-efficient and alternative technologies using propane in Russian were prepared and will be finalized with the support of international consultant.

baseline.comment: · Generally low awareness on new alternative technologies in the servicing sector and benefits in energy savings (co-benefits for economic operations as well as for climate change)

target.comment: · Local engineering companies gain knowledge and skills to assemble and operate such technologies in future

actual.comment:
Implementation of 3 demonstration projects expected to start in the next 2015/2016 reporting period.
Local experience with assembly of the refrigeration equipment of new non-ODS/low GWP technologies is expected to be gained once this sub-component is fully launched.
Additional reporting will be provided in next reporting cycle.

baseline.comment: · No current information products and programs

target.comment: · Safety standards for new alternatives reviewed and adopted

actual.comment: Activity is underway, and additional reports will be provided in future reporting cycle.

baseline.comment: · Lack of experience with, knowledge of and skills to assemble, install, operate and maintain HCFC-free commercial/industrial equipment using non-ODS/low-zero GWP technologies (NH3, CO2 double stage, HCs etc)

target.comment: · Performance of new equipment is regularly recorded

actual.comment:
Establishment of Refrigeration and air conditioning technicians Association (RACA) initiated, charter developed and submitted for legal registration.
The RACA will administrate activities on increasing experience, knowledge and skills to assemble, install, operate and maintain HCFC-free commercial/industrial equipment using non-ODS/low-zero GWP in Uzbekistan.
Draft guidance (manual) on energy-efficient and alternative technologies using propane in Russian prepared and will be finalized with the support of international consultant.

baseline.comment: · Low readiness for/acceptance of new technologies by users

target.comment: · Market is more prepared for the acceptance of new alternatives

actual.comment:
Research of local market on readiness of HCFC users to uptake new alternatives – ammonia, CO2 and HC technologies has been carried out and analysis of results is being performed,
Market research of prices and cost effectiveness of new alternative technologies is underway.
More reports to follow in the next reporting period.

indicator.title: Indicator 63
indicator.description: Railway Freezer Retrofit project for refrigerated transport sector - Yo'lreftrans

baseline.comment: · Weak basic servicing tooling of staff responsible for maintenance of the fleet and high refrigerant emissions due to transport and use specifics

target.comment: · Fleet retrofit at Yoâ€™lreftrans enterprise implemented and sustained during and beyond project duration

actual.comment:
With the project start after the inception workshop in September 2014, the needs of JSC “Yo’lreftrans” were assessed, and in response technical specifications of required equipment, tools and consumable goods were finalized in consulation with the stakeholder in order to prepare the company to launch the retrofits of its refrigeration railway fleet to non-ODS (HCFC, and some cases residual CFC) alternatives.
The following equipment was purchased and delivered to JSC "Yo'lreftrans": one (1) set of industrial type flushing system (Czech Ecotez produce) to enable cleaning of refrigeration circuits from remaining mineral oil used with HCFCs before retrofits, flushing agent (160 kg), limited stock of substitute gas (HFC134a - 2 tons) and synthetic oils (1.1 tons) miscible with HFCs. Though HFC134a is featured by 1,430 GWP factor, the replaced HCFC-22 has a factor of 1,810 in terms of GWP, and certain reductions in GWP effect can be demonstrated as a side-effect of the project. The need for single-component gas such as HFC134a in this initiative was justified in the project document since mobile railway transport with frequent vibrations of wagons and their refrigeration equipment results in frequent leaks and require quick maitenance with easy-to-use refrigerants, and other alternatives based on lower GWPs such as natural refrigerants are not well established, and new HFOs (development of HFCs) with very low GWP are too expensive at this moment due to starting production only in USA and not available on Uzbekistan market.
Project team plans for close regular consultations with JSC "Yo'lreftrans" on retrofit programme to establish appropriate trackable indicators of proress.
Further information will be provided in future reporting periods.

baseline.comment: · Limited scale retrofit of railway refrigerated equipment takes place which does not allow to reduce dependence on HCFCs - lack of specialized industrial sized circuit flushing units to allow for change from mineral to synthetic oils during retrofits

target.comment: · Company is fully equipped with required tools and seed funding for substitute materials to initiate large-scale retrofits of the refrigerated wagons fleet

actual.comment:
See detailed desription in the section above.
Company is fully equipped with the set of industrial type flushing system, flushing agent (160 kg), limited stock of ozone friendly refrigerants (R134a - 2 tons) and synthetic oils (1.1 tons).

baseline.comment: · Generally outdated refrigerant recycling equipment to address HCFC re-use in longer term

target.comment: · Staff is trained on correct use of equipment and tools, and applies best retrofit and equipment maintenance practices across workspace

actual.comment:
Training needs of the company have been properly assessed by the project team, and it is currently planned to deploy trainers to help the company have their refrigeration technicians fully prepared for retrofits.
Trainers will be coached and certified by the Galileo Refrigeration Training Institute (Italy) - through a regional component of the project.

indicator.title: Indicator 66
indicator.description: Upgrades of HCFC re-use system

baseline.comment: · HCFCs are not re-used domestically lack of a comprehensive HCFC re-use system, and country depends on imports

target.comment: · HCFC re-use system upgraded through strengthening R/R/R centers across the country in strategic locations countryâ€™s technical capacity is improved

actual.comment:
With the recruitment of project manager and inception workshop in September 2014, the project assessed national situation with current HCFC re-use system which includes ODS (HCFC)/HFC recovery (extraction from refrigeraton/AC equipment) and recylcing/reclaim (cleaning from acids/oils/impurities; storing; gas identification and equipment repair tools). Previous assistance in this sector in Uzbekistan was provided during beginning of 2000s, and equipment supplied at that time was mostly out of order by the time new HCFC project became operational.
Based on this review, national consultations on selecting future HCFC re-use centers were held, and technical plans of 5 HCFC recovery/recycling (R/R) and 1 HCFC reclaim centers across the country were prepared.
R/R centers will be established at existing refrigeration service companies “Shomur” (Fergana region), “Hladmontaj” (Andijan region), “Yolreftrans” (Syrdarya region), “Holod System” (Tashkent city) and “Pachenko” (Navoi region).
Reclaim center (ODS reclamation is a special cleaning process that decreases the level of impurities in used ODS gas to less than 1%, while recycling allows for 5% impurities) should be established at premises of the State Inspection on Analytical Control under State Committee for Nature Protection.
All these partners had provided co-financing letters during project formulation. Final list and technical specifications of equipment for recovery/recycling/reclaim centers was finalized and procurement (bidding) initiated.
As far as smaller servicing companies and individual technicans are concerned, the project announced tenders for supply of basic HCFC recovery/equipment repair tools. Overall, 125 sets of such tools will be delivered to Uzbekistan in the second half of 2015 for distribution. This will support the HCFC re-use network of R/R and reclaim centers, which in turn will provide ODS gas recuperation services to smaller service companies and enterpreneurs.

baseline.comment: · HCFC re-cycling and reclaim equipment, or network, is generally outdated and not suited for HCFCs in the former case and is absent in the latter

target.comment: · HCFC re-use system is implemented in practice allowing to reduce dependence on import of HCFCs

actual.comment:
Bidding for both R/R/reclaim centers and smaller service companies (tools) was completed, and modern equipment sets for R/R and reclamation of ODS (HCFC) gases is expected to reach Uzbekistan in September 2015 for distribution to the listed centers, and service tools for smaller companies are expected to be delivered later in 2015.
Additional information on progress will be provided in future reporting period.

baseline.comment: · Analytical equipment for servicing sector does not exist to ensure quality of re-cycled/reclaimed HCFC refrigerants and confidence of buyers

target.comment: · Technical center staff is trained on adequate use of equipment and best refrigeration practices in equipment maintenance and retrofits

actual.comment:
5 R/R and 1 reclaim centers will received training on the use of equipment with help of trainers to be coached and certified by the regional component's activities in Galileo Refrigeration Training Institute.
As for smaller service companies and individual technicians, project plans for a screening process to selected around 100 of such tool recipients in the second half of 2015. Received basic R/R tools will be distributed to those partners.

baseline.comment: · Limited active educational efforts or tools are available

target.comment: · Well informed stakeholder community engaged in addressing HCFC phase-out issue with required level of understanding and technical capacity

actual.comment:
Five (5) instructors are planned for participation in the international training in Italy at the Galileo Refrigeration Training Institute supported by the regional component of the project.
This training is expected to take place during Q3 of 2015.
All selected candidates (future instructors-trainers) developed their personal plans on organization of follow-up national trainings to be implemented after completion of ToT. Such follow-up trainings are planned to cover 800 refrigeration technicians across the country in the next 2015/2016 reporting period.

indicator.title: Indicator 70
indicator.description: Unwanted ODS Pilot Destruction Project

baseline.comment: · Limited negative experience of obsolete ODS destruction in a lab setting and lack of emission controls at existing prototype lab equipment

target.comment: · Small-scale obsolete ODS destruction capacity established on a pilot basis

actual.comment:
Based on market research, technical specification to initiate bidding process for purchase of small-scale ODS waste destruction unit finalized and agreed with/accepted by the national partner. Only one equipment manufacturer was identified, and resulting analysis/requests for clarification from the manufacturer on application of similar units indicated high operational cost and raw material usage (water, electricity).
In response to this, national partner (National Ozone Focal Point), UNDP-Tashkent and project team reached an agreement with the Ministry of Ecology of China and will organize a study tour to Guangzhou province to familiarize the delegation with the results of ODS destruction project implemented during 2013-2014 years, where such model of the ODS destruction unit (with same specifications) was in use. The visit is to take place in the second half of 2015 to determine feasibility of sustaining this unit using co-finance resources.
Further economic analysis of cost-effectiveness of the equipment may trigger procurement and installation in case national partner agrees to purchase this ODS destruction unit.

baseline.comment: · Further accumulation of obsolete ODS waste and the acute need to dispose of such wastes

target.comment: · Staff trained to operate and maintain equipment

actual.comment: Planned in future reporting period.

baseline.comment: · Small quantities of obsolete ODS waste to generate interest for export to major hazardous waste destruction sites

target.comment: · Stockpiles of obsolete ODS destroyed by supplied technology

actual.comment: Planned in future reporting period when equipment will be installed

baseline.comment: · Lack of integration of ODS disposal into HCFC re-use system to complete ODS management cycle

target.comment: · Dissemination of results performed on the regional scale

actual.comment:
Planned in future reporting period when equipment will be installed.
The work on this component will be complemented by sub-component 4 of the regional umbrella programme related to the inter-country counsultations on HCFC waste strategy that will be implemented during 2015/2016

baseline.comment: · Generally lack of appropriate ODS destruction experience in Central Asia region

actual.comment: Planned in future reporting period when equipment will be installed.

indicator.title: Indicator 75
indicator.description: Targeted HCFC Phase-out Investment Program and Demonstration projects (Ukraine)

target.comment: description provided in sections below

actual.comment:
Due to political and economic crisis in Ukraine, hybrid war in two Eastern regions of Ukraine, sharp devaluation of national currency by 3 times and following inflation during one year, only one eligible company (out of four), Polyfoam, has stayed in the investment component (manufacturing sector).
This change releases 70% of the budget in the current project for Ukraine, and these circumstances demanded consideration fro decision making on the future of this component.
Based on consultations with the project team, and lead technical department of UNDP and assinged international expert on HCFC strategy formulation, it was proposed and agreed to design a two-stage project revision process: (1) light revision which does not require approval from GEF to optimize workplans and budgets for those project partners which stay with the project, and (2) the deeper project revision, based on HCFC strategy's outcomes to be received later in 2015/2016, in consultations with GEF for the remaining funds rephasal to servicing sector.
In the first round of "light" revision, Polifoam company's sub-component has been subject of review and additional consultations in the reporting period, and the project design was agreed to be shifted from capital equipment support to formulation of required ODS-free/low GWP chemical formulas for better uptake of these by downstream clients, plus high-pressure, low-pressure and spray equipment packages for such clients. This sub-component is explained in more detail below in the Polifoam's related section.
In the first round, the project will further support drafting legislative improvements, as recommended by assigned international expert on HCFC control framework (regional component of the project, Customs with training and analytical equipment to better control import of HCFCs, and will plan to initiate demonstration on partial supply of modern HCFC recovery and recycling tools to one of refrigeration equipment service centers which would be selected to undergo trainings on best HCFC management practices in Galileo Refrigeration Training Institute in Italy. This would serve as an example of project activities for other potential partners in the servicing sector to generate more solid interest for cooperation after second "deeper" revision of the project document is approved.

indicator.title: Indicator 76
indicator.description: Information exchange platform on HCFC substitute technologies for ineligible foam manufacturers (PU and XPS) companies

baseline.comment: Low level of awareness related to HCFC phase-out across stakeholders from manufacturing sector;

target.comment: Main stakeholders in the manufacturing sector are informed about new and emerging alternative technologies and various capital/operating investment aspects;

actual.comment:
HCFC data collection (after initial delay) is being launched by the project team, and this will help design draft national HCFC phase-out strategy. The data collection covers also foam enterprises (PU, XPS and system houses) to understand changes in the original project's baseline.
Based on this activity, project team will plan such information exchange in the foam sector once all actors have been fully identified.
Activity planned for future reporting cycles.

baseline.comment: No current information products and programs on information dissemination related to alternative technologies in the manufacturing sector;

target.comment: At least, four (4) of the ineligible enterprises self-convert to other than HCFC technological solutions without GEF assistance;

actual.comment:
General review performed by the project team on the changes induced by political instability and economic crisis in Ukraine, specifically in the foam sector, indicated a strong prospect for bankruptcy for XPS industry which was at the time of project preparation responsible for 50% of HCFC consumption in Ukraine.
Based on the starting HCFC import and consumption data collection which includes top-down (Customs/HCFC import licensing system) and bottom-up (based on end-user survey) approaches, a survey will be made in the foam sector on remaining factories involved into PU and XPS foam manufacturing to understand the prospects related to self-conversion of GEF ineligible companies.
Current information that is avialable informs that Sobraniye XPS company (with 3 plants) is fully stopped and a bankrupt, where one plant was expected to go for self-conversion based on Sobraniye's co-finance. Intertehnika PU foam company self-converted, though was part of the original project, and changed ownership in the area of armed conflict.
Further information will be provided in future reporting periods.

baseline.comment: Nine (9) manufacturing enterprises continue to rely on HCFCs as the only technological solution in the absence of knowledge on a range of new and emerging alternatives which may minimize capital investments.

target.comment: HCFC consumption is accordingly reduced by respective annual consumption amounts at a number of self-converted enterprises.

actual.comment:
Based on Article 7 (annual HCFC data reporting requirement of the Montreal Protocol), National Ozone Office of Ukraine provided reporting to the Ozone Secretariat (UNEP/Nairobi) that its HCFC import in 2014 was featured by a downward trend approaching to 2015 (90% cut of baseline HCFC consumption) milestone.
This indirect indicator demonstrates that HCFC import/consumption is gradually dropping. At the same time the bottom-up HCFC survey which is now starting may help reveal unaccounted consumption as was the case during this project formulation and the situation escalated to its review by the Implemenation Committee of the Montreal Protocol on non-compliance.
Updates in this respect will be available after HCFC survey is completed.

indicator.title: Indicator 79
indicator.description: Implementation of a system house conversion project at Polyfoam

baseline.comment: Polyfoam (system house) and its downstream users continue to depend on HCFC-141b in polyol blending and consumption;

target.comment: Polyfoam and its downstream users are technologically converted to non-ODS/ low GWP technology (methyl formate)

actual.comment:
During reporting period, Polifoam (city of Dneprodzerjinsk) stayed as the only financially viable and accessible company left in the manufacturing sector in the project.
The project arranged for a (South-South) study tour to a Brazil-based System House of Purcom in March 2015. The reason for the visit was the need to confirm methyl formate (MF) blend's chemical composition and infrastructure at Purcom (being one of the advanced system houses globally with MF introduced). Polyfoam brought samples of MF blend for direct use in its laboratory and then trial production which did not perform well in certain applications such as for refrigeration manufacturing (low density).
Previously recruited international foam expert refused to continue with this assignment by referring to ongoing military conflict in the country. In response, a special visit was arranged by one of UNDP lead foam experts in May 2015 to identify issues with MF trials at Polifoam, and subsequently revisions were proposed to Polifoam project document design and its budget (upward but within existing donor funding rules) to match it better to the needs on the ground.
New TOR/recruitment process is underway to identify a suitable foam expert to continue providing assistance to Polifoam.
Revisions in the Polifoam sub-component are planned for official approval by a project board in the second half of 2015. Implementation of the revised project can start in October/November 2015.
Direct contractual modality for implementation of Polifoam project has been proposed based on successful experience in Brazil.

baseline.comment: Alternative technologies are scarcely available to the company, and its downstream clients, for access and transfer, not tested at the facility and lack processing and safety instrumentation for practical introduction;

target.comment: HCFC use at Polyfoam stopped and company committed not to use HCFCs any longer

actual.comment:
See information above.
Revision of this sub-component is ongoing, and implementation will start after its approval at a project board in the second half of 2015.

baseline.comment: No current information products and programs on information dissemination related to the proposed alternative technologies in the manufacturing sector.

target.comment: Technical staff is knowledgeable on correct use of new technology

actual.comment:
See information above.
Revision of this sub-component is ongoing, and implementation will start after its approval at a project board in the second half of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 82
indicator.description: Implementation of a foam conversion project at Intertehnika

baseline.comment: Intertehnika (commercial refrigeration manufacturing) depends on HCFC-141b in its manufacturing processes (either of domestic manufacture or import);

target.comment: Intertehnika technologically converted to non-ODS/ low GWP technology (HCFC-141b based polyols to c-pentane)

actual.comment:
The company is not accessible because it is situated in the area of armed conflict, and changed ownership, as reported by former focal company's focal points through the project manager. Intertehnika was a part of the Nord Holding Group.
Before these events, the company reportedly self-converted to the use of hydrocarbons when its production facility was relocated to main Nord facility where production process is based on hydrocabons (no ozone depletion potential, low GWP).
This project partner is planned for removal from participation in the project which will be discussed and endorsed in a project board meeting in the second half of 2015.
Contract with international foam expert expired, and will not be resumed.
Unused funding from this sub-component will be applied in the second round of the programme revision towards assistance to the servicing sector.
Next year reporting only will focus on confirmation of cancellation of this sub-component

baseline.comment: Alternative technologies are scarcely available to the company for access and transfer, not tested at the facility and lack processing and safety instrumentation for practical introduction;

target.comment: HCFC use at Intertehnika stopped and company committed not to use HCFCs any longer

actual.comment: According to reports from former owners of the company, Intertehnika had self-converted to hydrocarbons after its facility (commercial refrigeration equipment - drinks stands, etc) was co-located with main Nord facility (domestic refrigeration) before armed conflict developed and it changed ownership.

baseline.comment: Commercial equipment manufactured by the company continues to be produced with HCFC-141b in foam insulation.

target.comment: Technical staff is knowledgeable on correct use of new technology

actual.comment:
See above.
No more activities planned - sub-component will be cancelled.

indicator.title: Indicator 85
indicator.description: Implementation of a foam conversion project at Sobraniye

baseline.comment: Sobraniye (XPS foam product manufacturer) depends on HCFCs (R-22 and sporadically 141b) in its manufacturing processes;

target.comment: Sobraniye technologically converted to non-ODS/ low GWP technology (to carbon dioxide technology);

actual.comment:
The company is bankrupted due to the overall financial situation in the country developed with political instability and military activities.
The reason for stopping economic activities at this company was related to increase in the cost of raw materials. Input resource material (XPS pellets) which is used in the manufacturing of XPS plank (10 mm or other sized insulation sheets) was in abundant supply before 2014/2015 based on tax-reduced imports from the Russian Federation. When economic ties with the Russian Federation started to deteriorate, the supply of pellets gradually stopped. New imports of the raw material was possible from China, but with added VAT and import taxes which increased the cost of marketed products to a level of not being able to compete with imported ready XPS plank from other countries, mostly EU.
No any additional activities planned for this company, and unused funding is planned for redistribution to the servicing sector.
This decision will be taken at a project board meeting in the second half of 2015.

baseline.comment: Alternative technologies are scarcely available to the company for access and transfer, not tested at the facility and lack processing and safety instrumentation for practical introduction

target.comment: HCFC use at Sobraniye stopped and company committed not to use HCFCs any longer;

actual.comment:
Company is bankrupted. No HCFC is in use.
No more activities planned - sub-component will be cancelled.

baseline.comment: Refrigerated trucks with foam insulation continue to be manufactured with the use of HCFCs

target.comment: Technical staff is knowledgeable on correct use of new technology.

actual.comment:
See above.
No more activities planned - sub-component will be cancelled.

indicator.title: Indicator 88
indicator.description: Implementation of a solvent conversion project at Nord

baseline.comment: Nord (solvent user) depends on HCFC-141b in manufacturing processes and this is a high emissive use of HCFCs;

target.comment: Nord technologically converted to non-ODS technology (HCFC-141b to transblends based on HFCs closed loop cycle and minimization of agent use reduce emissions);

actual.comment:
The company is not accessible because it is situated in the area of armed conflict, and changed ownership, as reported by former focal company's focal points through the project manager.
This project partner is planned for removal from participation in the project which will be discussed and endorsed in a project board meeting in the second half of 2015.
Contract with international solvent expert expired, and will not be resumed.
Unused funding from this sub-component will be applied in the second round of the programme revision towards assistance to the servicing sector.
Next year reporting only will focus on confirmation of cancellation of this sub-component

baseline.comment: Alternative technologies are scarcely available to the company for access and transfer, not tested at the facility and lack processing and safety instrumentation for practical introduction;

target.comment: HCFC use at Nord stopped and company committed not to use HCFCs any longer;

actual.comment:
See above.
No more activities planned - sub-component will be cancelled.

baseline.comment: Spares (compressors and others) for refrigerators continue to be manufactured with the use of HCFC-141b as a degreasing agent.

target.comment: Technical staff is knowledgeable on correct use of new technology.

actual.comment:
See above.
No more activities planned - sub-component will be cancelled.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback, outreach and evaluation

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: M&E and adaptive management applied to project in response to needs, mid-term evaluation findings with lessons learned extracted.

baseline.comment: ·  No Monitoring and Evaluation system

target.comment: ·  Monitoring and Evaluation system developed during year 1.

actual.comment:
Project monitoring was conducted in accordance with Monintoring and Evaluation Plan.
Progress quarterly, semester and annual reports on the project implementation were duly prepared.
Detailed workplans and project budgets were prepared, reviewed/revised and updated in due time in response to the identified changes in current needs and requirements.
Evaluation framework was discussed with partner countries during the project review meeting in Istanbul in June 2015 (in UNDP Regional Office). The mid-term evaluation of the projects in all four (4) countries and the regional component will be managed by the regional center (one recruitment process for one evaluation expert with combined financial resources coming from all respective projects) and will take place in October-November 2015.

baseline.comment: ·  No evaluation of project output and outcomes

target.comment: ·  Mid-term-evaluation of project output and outcomes conducted with lessons learnt at 30 months of implementation.

actual.comment:
During the project board meeting in June 2015, it was agreed with all four (4) countries that one evaluator would be recruited for the assignment to ensure consistent reporting in one document. This excercise will be managed by the regional component of the GEF/HCFC project with resources to be provided by each national component.
Mid-term evaluation process is planned for launching in the second half od 2015 with the report to be ready early 2016 depending on missions schedules to each participating country.

target.comment: ·  Final evaluation report ready in the end of project

actual.comment: Planned for March 2018 (after 2 year extension in March 2016 is granted)
